OPINIONS OF T H E PItE£*» t

The principal piece was O ' F I . A N N I G A N
AND THE F A I R I E S , ilw plot of which turns 011
the mystification which besots a good.humoured
native of the 'Green Isle,' in consequence, of his
too ftrung attachment of whisky. This extras*.iganza afforded an opiwrtunity for the introduction
of P O W E R , whose rich humour, combined with
his genuine Irish manner, kept the house in a
roar of laughter from the beginning to the end of
the performance.
' O'Flannigan'* appearance'
every night till further notice was announced with
universal approbation."—The. Timet.
" O ' F L A N N I G A N A N D T U B F A I R I E S " ; >r, A
MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S
DuhXH,(notSlmksfmtre's)

was produced for the first time. Mr. P O W E R infused into i t all his wonted point and spirit, and
constructed as it is in the business ami the dialogue of the scenes, furnish rich and ample scope
for the peculiar quaintness of manner that has
acquired him the celebrity in which h e may well
rejoice. I lis jokes and equivoque as lie gave them
told to the utmost, and kept the house always in
t h e best of good humour, and called upon their
risible faculties most extravagantly.
The piece
has been got up in capital style, and at the conclusion P O W E R was called for, and was most
heartily congratulated. H e announced it for repetition every night amidst loud applause."—Bell's
Weekly Messenger.
" There is no theatre in London where a better evening's amusement can be obtain* d than at
the Haymarket, or where a better company can be
found.

O ' F L . I N N I G A M ANI> T H E F A I R I E S , was

of course the principal attraction of the evening;
Ui. bewilderment/and incredulity ofPJulim, are
comic in the highest degree, ami do infinite
credit to Mr. P O W E R ; he has also an excellent drunken scene, in which ho cons over by
the light of a latithorn the rules and regulations
laid down by himself against future excess in his
. ' p u b l i c and private dhrinks.' and which, like
the filial clauses of an act of parliament, have loopholes big enough to roll a dozen hogsheads of
whisky through them. The last act is by far the
best, and in itself will repay the visitor. At its
conclusion, P O W E R informed the audience that
Mrs.O'Fttimtigitn would have a 'small toy'party'
OH the following evening, to which be invited
them till; and from the hearty manner in which
they bestowed their applause, all seemed bent
upon ' making one.'—S nlay Times.
" O ' F L A N N I G I N AND T H E F A I R I E S ; or, A
M I D S U M M E R N I G H T ' S D R E A M , alleged not to

have been written by Shakspeare, gave an opportunity for the irresistible comicality of P O W E R .
I t was for the ttrst time produced at this theatre,
but will certainly not be the last, the audience
having testified their approbation in a very marked manner. The piece ts altogether exceedingly
well got up, and gives opportunity for the indulgence of all P O W E R ' S peculiarities and humorous
songs, in which he is most ably assisted by the
genuine simplicity and archness of Mrs. F I T Z W I L L I A M , who personates ,Mary, in which character she sing* verysweetly two or three favorite
ballads."— The Torch.
«'The Haymarket fairy piece is a concoction
of P O W E R ' S own ingenuity, and owes alt its fun
to his inimitable acting of the Irish « 6oy,' who,
in order to get a wife, makes a vow to abstain from
drinking ana fighting for a whole year; but, breaking it, he has a dream full of funny horrors, whieh
a r e enacted on the stage, to the infinite amusement
of everybody ; the dreamer figuring, in propria
persona, as the hero of the droll adventures."—
The Alhtna-um.
' • O ' F L A N N I G A N AND T H E F A I R I E S , in which

P O W E R is of course the •be-all and the end-all,'
T h e illustrious ' HibernianPersonator' is, if possible, more redolent of humour than ever. T h e
getting up of the piece is unexceptionable, and it
was exceedingly well received."— Weekly Dispatch
Moated Oir«kr, Mr REEK.

" One of the best Christmas Pieces that hive
been produced is (he amusing e x t r a v a g a n t
brought out at the Hay market, and called

O ' F L A N N I G A N AND T H E F A I R I E S a d r a m a t k i n g

of the Irish fairy legend, called, « H i e over to
England.' There are several amusing scenes in
the course of the piewe, one of the bsst being
the fair scene, with a skirmish among the boys,
ending with not a few broken bends. I t were,
p e r h a p s needless to my that, as to Power was
entrusted the task of delineating the peculiarities
of a light-hearted
and light-headed broth of a
Ixiy, he acquitted himself of his (ask, and t h e
piece was given out for repetition without a dissentient voice."—Court Journal.
" The principal attraction at this theatre, on
Wednesday, was the fairy piece, O ' F L A N N I G A N
AND T H E F A I R I E S , in which Power wont through
the part with his usual buoyancy of spirit, and
produced shouts of laughter by his drolleries a s
the unfortunate Phelim O'Ftanmgan.
The piece
has been well got up, and does iiifiuite credit to
the management."—The Age.
" On Wednesday night, a piece, entitled O '
F L A N N I G A N A N D T H E F A I R I E S , dramatized from

a collection of Irish Fairy Tales.after the fashion
of ' O'llourke and the Eagle,' was produced with
great success. This piece is grounded upon t h e
drunken adventures of O'F/«»i-.>0«w(Mr.PowER)
who in his potations, wanders among the fairies
on the eve of his marriage ; and his frolics among
the 'good people,' although not exactly in the
manner of Tiianiu, Oberan and Bully Bottom, are
irresistibly ludicrous.
Mrs- F I T Z W J L L I A M , as
Mart/ his intended, looked, acted, and sang very
sweetlv, and the house was in a roar from the commencement till the fall of the curtain."—Atlas.
" Mr. P O W E R , in a tale of the Irish fairies,
embodied all the humours and was a fit representative of all the gladness, that are peculiar to the
Reason.

O'FLANNIOAN

AND T H E F A I R I E S , a n

excellent womk romance by M r . P O W E R himself,
will no doubt have a most successful holiday run."
—Examiner.
" P O W E R is the life and soul of the fun; how
he breaks his vow of tee-totalisui and temperance,
(in the use of the shilelagh,) and dreams a dream
full of grotesque horrors, and is transported to the
clouds in a donkey-cart.
T h e ' fight' and the
•jig' would be alone worth seeing, were there
nothing else to be enjoyed."—The Spectator.
• ' O ' F L A N N I G A N A N D T H B F A I R I E S is co-

mic in the highest degree, and with the aid of
singing, jigging, fighting, and fairy fun, we doubt
not that P O W E R ' S Phelim O'Fiannigun will have
a most successful holiday run."—Post and Sun.
" H e r e P O W E R was the Pantomime, in
O'FLANNIGAN

AND T H E F A I H I E S ; and

if to

keep a house in roars of laughter, for a whole
evening, b . a test of success, we may say that
never were Harlequin, Columbine, Clown and
Pantaloon, rolled into one more effectually."—
Literary Gazette.
•'O'FLANNIGAN

AND T H E F A I R I E S

is a

vehicle for Mr. P O W E R ' S inimitable Irishisms,
whimsicalities,and eomicalities.whieh render him
the bestd.lineator of true Irish character extant.
T h e piece was very laughable, and the dialogue
was occasionally relieved by a grotesque dance,
an Irish j i g , or a familiar and pleasing Irish
melody, which excited considerable applause.
T h e piece was announced for repetition without a
singledissentient voice."—Morning U*rald$$Globe
" All the fun of the piece, which is of a
most extravagant and bustling character, rests
upon the shoulders of our inimitable friend, Mr.
P O W E R . In a word, the audience were kept in a
roar of laughter from the very outset to the final
fall ef t h e curtain, and the piece was given out
for repetition every evening amidst a thunder of
applause.—Chronicle.

AND T H E F A I R I KM, tins ptot of which turns on
the mystification which besets a good humoured
native of the 'Green Isle,' in consequence of his
too strong attachment of whisky. This extravaganza afforded an opportunity for the introduction
of P O W E R , whose rich humour, combined with
his genuine Irish manner, kept the house in a
roar of laughter from the beginning to the end of
the performance.
' O'Flannigan * appearance'
every night till further notice was announced with
universal approbation."—The Times.
" O ' F L A N N I G A N A N D T H E F A I R I E S ; or, A

MlDsUMMEU N I G H T ' S ])uhAM,(»r>r Shnkspeart's)
was produced for tha first time. Mr. P o w KR infused into it all his wonted point and spirit, and
constructed as it is in the business and the dialogue of the scenes, furnish rich and ample scope
for the peculiar quaintness of manner that has
acquired him the celebrity in which he may well
rejoice. His jokes and equivoque us he gave them
told to the utmost, and kept the house always in
the best of good humour, and called upon their
risible faculties most extravagantly. The piece
has been got u p in capital style, and at the conclusion P O W E R was called for, and was most
heartily congratulated. Ho announced it for repetition every night amidst loud applause."—Bell's
Weekly Messenger.

" T h e Haymarket fairy piece is a concoction
of P O W E R ' S own ingenuity, and owes all its fun

to bis inimitable acting of t h e Irish ' boy,' who,
in order to get a wife, makes a vow to abstain from
drinking and fighting for a whole year;but, breaking it, he has a dream full of funny horrors, which
nr* enacted on the stage, to the infinite amusement
of everybody ; the dtearaer figuring, in propria
permit?, as tins hero ©f the droll adventures."—

ttill Hiurrr* amongst the peasantry, one of the ;no-I noeticai of our mt'onal superstitions, and highly congenial to Ihe temperament of an imaginative prople.
ITiis Drama, however, present, lh« " G o o d People" in dream only, the action of Ihe piece, from the time the fairies appear, until the sleeping O'Klanniara*
awake* once more to a working day world, existing only hi the creations of a wild fellow's brain fired by whiskey, and disordered by hard blows. H i .
imaginary peril* and sufferings being at M i l the rnnseqaence of his Intemperance* and the moral punishment of the relapsed whisker lover.

THE ONLY SUCCESSFUL CHRISTMAS PIECE.

AND THE FAIRIES:

A Midsummer Nights Dream,—not Shakspeare's.

" T h e principal piece was O ' F I . A N N I G A N
AND T H E F A I R I E S , tli* plot of which turns on
th* mystification which besets a good humoured
native of the 'Green Isle,' in consequence of his
too strong attachment of whisky. This extravaganza afforded an opportunity for the intioduction
of P O W E R , whose rich humour, combined with
his genuine Irish manner, kept the house in a
roar of laughter from the beginning to the end of
the performance.
'O'Fiannigan's appearance'
every night till further notice was announced with
universal approbation."—The Times.

jj
** One of the best Christmas Pieces that have
| been produced is the amusing extravaganza

of the Irish fairy legend, called, * Hie over to
England.' There are several amusing scenes in
the course of the pieee, one of the best being
the fair scene, with a skirmish among t h e boys,

perhaps, needless to say that, as to Power was
entrusted the task of delineating the peculiarities
of a light-hearted
and liaht-headed broth of a
boy, he acquitted himself of his task, and t h e

i

" O ' F u N M f i t N AND T H E F A I R I E S ; or, A
M I D S U M M E R N I G H T ' S D R E A M , alleged not to

have been written by Shakspenre, gave an opportunity for the irresistible comicality of P O W E R .
I t was for the first time produced at this theatre,
but will certainly not be the last, the audience
having testified their approbation in a very marked manner- The piece is altogether exceedingly
well got up, and gives opportunity for the indulgence of all P O W E R ' S peculiarities and humorous
sonws, in which he is roost ably assisted by the
genuine simplicity and archness of Mrs. F I T Z W I L L I A M , who personates Mary, fa which character she sings very sweetly two or three favorite
ballads."—TA* Torch.
" T h e H a y market fairy piece is a concoction
of P O W E R ' S own ingenuity, and owes all its fun
to bis inimitable acting of t h e Irish ' boy' who,
in order to get a wife, makes a vow to abstain from
drinking and fighting for a whole year; but, breaking it, he has a dream full of ftnwy horrors, which
are enacted on the stage, to the infinite amusement
of everybody ; the dreamer figuring, in propria
persowr, as the hero of the droll adventures."—
The Jtherueum.
" O ' F L A N N I G A N AND T H E F A i n i E s . i n which
P O W E R is of course the «be-all and the end-all.'
T h e illustrious ' HibernianPersonator' is, if possible, more redolent of humour than ever. T h e
getting up of the piece is unexceptionable, and i t
was exceedingly well received."—WeekfyDUpatck

" O'FLANNIGAN

AND T H E F A I R I E S is co-

mic in the highest degree, and with the aid of
singing, jigging, fighting, and fairy fun, we doubt
not that P O W E R ' S PAelim O'Flannignn will have
a most successful holiday run."—Post and Sim.
" H e r e P O W E R was the Pantomime, in
O'FLANNIGAN

ANU T H E F A i u i s s ; a n d

if to

keep a house in paws of laughter, for a whole
evening, be a test of success, we may say that
never were Harlequin, Columbine, Clown and
Pantaloon, rolled into one more effectually."—
Literary Gazette.
" O ' PtANNlGAN

AND T H E F A I R I E S

is 8

vehicle for Mr P O W E R ' S inimitable Irishisms,
whimsicalities, and comicalities,which render him
the best d.Hneator of true Irish character extant,
^ h e piece was very laughable, and the dialogue
was occasionally relieved by a grotesque dance,
an Irish j i g , or a familiar and pleasing Irish
melody, which excited considerable applause.
T h e piece was announced for repetiti.n without a
single dissentient voice."- Morning HeraldfyGlobe
« All the fun ©f the piece, which is of a
most extravagant and bustling character, rests
upon the shoulders of our inimitable friend, Mr.
P O W E R . In a word, th« audience were kept in a
roar of laughter from tae very outset to the final
fall of the curtain, atsd the piece was given out
for repetition every evening amidst a thunder of
applause.—Chronicle.

OPINIONS OF THE
" T h e principal piece was 0 ' F I . A M N I O A N
I N K T H E F A I R I E S , t h . plot of which turn- on
t b . mystification which besets a good humoured
Mfitf of the 'Green Isle,' in consequence of his
too strong attachment of whisky. This extravaganza afforded an opportunity for the intioduction
of P O W E R , whose rich humour, combined with
his genuine Irish manner, kept the house in a
mar of laughter from the beginning to the end of
the performance.
'O'Flanaigan's appearance'
every wight till further notice was announced with
universal approbation."—The Timts.
" O ' F L A N N I C S A N AND T H E F A I R I E S ; or, A

M I D S U M M E R NioiiT'8Dii*.AM,(>to[.SiA(//<-«p«ir.'*)

was produced for the first time. Mr. P O W E R infused into it all his wonted point and Spirit, and
constructed as it is in the business- and the dialogue of the scenes, furnish rich and ample scope
for the peculiar quaintness of manner that h a s
acquired him the celebrity in which he may well
rejoice. His jokes and equivoque as he gave them
told to the utmost, and kept the house always in
the best of good humour, and called upon their
risible faculties most extravagantly. The piece
has been got up in capital style, and at the conclusion P O W E R was called for, and w a s most
heartily congratulated. He announced it for repetition every night amidst loud applause."—Bull's
Weekly Ik/estengcx.
" There is no theatre in London where a better evening's amusement can be obtained than at
the Haymarket, or where a bettor company can be
found.

O ' F L A N N I Q A M ANI> T H E F A I R I E S , was

of course the principal attraction of the evening;
the bewilderment and incredulity of P/ulim, are
comic in the highest degree, and do infinite
credit to Mr. P O W E R ; he has also an e x cellent drunken scene, in which he cons over by
the light of a lanthorn the rules and regulations
laid down by himself against future excess in bis
'public and private d brinks,' and which, like
the final clauses of an act of parliament, have loopholes big enough to roll a dozen hogsheads of
whisky through ihem. The last act is by far the
best, and in itself will repay the visitor. At its
conclusion, P o w E R informed the audienee that
Mrs, O' Flatrnttgan would have a ' small toy party'
on the following evening, to which he invited
them a l l ; and ft om the hearty manner in which
they bestowed their applause, all seemed bent
MfMMt ' making one.'—Sunday Timet.
" O ' F L A N N I O A N AND T H E F A I R I E S ; or, A

"MtDsuMMKti N I G H T ' S D R E A M , alleged not to

have been written by Sbakspeare, save an opportunity for the irresistible comicality of P O W E R .
I t was for the first time produced at this theatre,
but will certainly not be the last, the audience
having testified their approbation in a very marked manner. The piece is altogether exceedingly
well got tip, and gives opportunity for t h e indulgence of .11 P O W E R ' S peculiarities and humorous
songs, in which he is most ablv assisted bv the
guttttitte simplicity and archness of Mr-. P i T z WtlLMAW, who personates Mary, in which character she tings very sweetly two or three favorite
ballads."—r*« TWcft.
" The Haymarket fairy piece is a concoction
of P O W E R ' S own ingenuity, and owes all i t . fun
to bis inimitable acting of t h e Irmh ' 6ojr,' who,
in order to get a wife, makes a vow to abstain from
drinking and fighting for a whole year;bat, breaking it, be has a dream full of funny horrors, which
a r e enacted on the stage, tothe infinite amusement
of everybody ; the dreamer figuring, t'» prtiprm
persona, as the hero of the droll adventure*."-—.
The Athenaeum.
"O'FlANNIOAJJAND THE F A IRIES, in which
P O W E R is of course the 'be-all and the end-all.*
The illustrious * Hibernian Persouator' Is, if w » sible, more redolent of humour than ever. T i l .
getting up of the piece is unexceptionable, and it
t u exceedingly well reeei-ed."—Weekly Dispatch

O ' F L A N R I U A N AND THE F A I R I E S , adramatizing

of the Irish fairy legend, called, ' Hie over to
England-' There are several amusing scenes in
the course of the pieee, one of the best being
the fair seems with a skirmish among the boye,
ending with not u few broken heads. I t were,
perhaps, needless to any that, as to Power was
entrested the task of delineating the peculiarities
of a light-henrfd
and light-headed broth of a
boy, h e acquitted himself of his task, and t h .
piece was given out for repetition without a diesentient voiee,"—Court Journal.
" The principal attraction at this theatre, on
Wednesday, was the fairy piece, O ' F L A N N I O A H
AND T H E F A I R I E S , in which Power went through
the part with his nsual buoyancy of spirit, and
produced shouts of laughter by his drolleries a s
the unfortunate Phelim (fFlanntgan.
T h e piece
has been well got u p , and does infinite credit to
the management."—The Ag*.
'* On Wednesday night, a piece, entitled O*
F L A N N I G A N AND T H K F A I R I E S , dramatized from

a collection of Irish Fairy Tales.after the fashion
of ' O'Rourke and the Eagle,' was produced with
great success. This piece is grounded upon t h e
drunken adventures of 0'F/«ww<<7«n(Mr.PoWER)
who, in bis potations, wanders among t h e fairies
on the eve of his marriage ; and his frolics among
the ' good people,' although not exactly in t h .
manner of Titania, Obeyon and Bully Bottom, a r e
irresistibly ludicrous. Mrs. F I T Z W I L L I A M , a s
Mm-if his intended, looked, acted, and sang very
sweetly, and the house was in a roar from t h e commencement till the fall of the curtain."—Atlas" Mr. P O W E R , in a tale of the Irish fairies,
embodied all the humours and was a fit representative of all the gladness, that are peculiar to t h .
season.

O'FLANNUMN

\ N D T H E F A I R I E S , an

excellent •,omic romance by Mr. P O W E R himself,
will no doubt have a must successful holiday run."
—H.raminer.
" P O W K U is the life and soul of the fun ; how
he breaks bis vow of tee-totalism and temperance,
(in the use of the shilelagh,) and dreams a dream
full of grotesque horrors, and is transportedtot h e
clouds in a donkey-cnrt.
T h e ' fight' and t h e
•jig' would be alone worth seeing, were there
nothing else to be enjoyed."— The Spectator.
" O ' F L A N N I O A N A N D T H K F A I R I E S is c o -

mie in the highest degree, and with t h e aid of
singing, jigging, fighting, and fairy fun, we doubt
not that P O W E R ' S Phelim O'Flannigan will have
a most successful holiday run."—Pout and Sim.
" H e r e P O W E R was the Pantomime, in
O'FLANNIOAN

AND T H E F A I R I E S ; and if to

keep a house in roars of laughter, for it whole
evening, be a test of success, we may say that
never were Harlequin, Columbine, Clown and
Pantaloon, rolled into one more effectually,"JMtrary
Gaxtttt.

OPINIONS OF THE
" Tho principal piece wag O ' F I . A N N I G A N
AND T H E F A I R I E S , the plot of which turns on
the mystification which besets a good humoured
native of the 'Green Isle,' in consequence of his
too strong attachment of whisky. This extravaganza aflorded an opportunity for the intioduction
of P O W E R , whose rich humour, comhined with
his,genuine Irish manuer, kept the house in a
roar of laughter from the beginning to the end of
the performance.
'O'Fhinuigan's appearance'
every night till further notice was announced with
universal approbation."—The Times.
" O ' F L A N N I G A N A N D T H K F A I R I E H ; or, A
M I D S v M MKU N i o HT'S D R E A M , {not Shakspeare's)

was produced for the first time. Mr. P O W E R infused into it all his wonted point and spirit, nnd
constructed as it is in the business ami the dialogue of the scenes, furnish rich and ample scope
for the peculiar quaintness of manner that has
acquired him the celebrity in which he may well
rejoice- His jokes and equivoque as he gave them
told to the utmost, and kept the house always in
the best of good humour, and called upon their
risible faculties most extravagantly.
The piece
has been got up in capital style, and at the conclusion P O W E R was called for, and was most
heartily congratulated. H e announced it for-repetition every night amidst loud applause."'—Bell's
Weekly Mviseuger.
" There is no theatre in London where a better evening's amusement can be obtained than a t
the Haymarket, or where a better company can be
foHnd. O'FutNNlGAN AND THK FA \ Rl KS, was
of course the principal attraction of the evening;
the bewilderment and incredulity of Pluiim, are
comic in the highest degree, and do infinite
credit to M r . P O W E R ; lie h a s also an e x cellent drunken scene, in which he cons over by
the light of a lanthorn the rules and regulations
laid down by himself against future excess in his
•public and private dhiinks,' and which, like
the final clauses of an act of parliament, have loopholes big enough to roll a doses hogsheads of
whisky through them. The last act is by far the
best, and in itself will repay the visitor. At its
conclusion, P O W E R informed the audience that
Mis.G'Planniaan
would have a 'small lay party'
on the. following evening, to which he invited
them a l l ; and from the hearty manner in which
they bestowed their applause, all seemed bent
upon 'making one'—Sundtiy Times.
" O ' F L A N N I C A N AND T H E F A I R I E S ; or, A
M I D S U M M E R N I O H T ' S D R E A M , alleged not to

have been written by Shakspeare, save an opportunity for the Irresistible comicality of P O W E R .
I t was for the firnt time produced at this theatre,
hut will certainly not be the last, the audience
having testified their approbation in a very marked manner. T h e piece is altogether exceedingly
well got up, and gives opportunity for the indulgence of all P O W E R ' S peculiarities and humorous
songs, in which he is most ably assisted by the
genuine simplicity and archness ot Mrs. F I T Z wiLl.iAM, who person Ates M<try, in which character she sings very sweetly two or three favorite
ballads."— The Torch.
" The Haymarket fairy piece is a concoction
of P O W E B ' S own ingenuity, and owes all its fun
to his inimitable acting of the Irish * boy,' who,
in order to get a wife, makes a vow to abstain from
drinking and fighting for a whole year; but, breaking it, he has a dream full of funny horrors, which
are enacted on the stage, tothe infinite amusement
of everybody ; the dreamer figuring, in propria
persome, as the hero of the droll adventures."—
The Athenaeum.
" O ' F L A N N I O A N AND T H E F A tRt KS, in which

P O W E R is of course the 'be-all and the end-all.'
The illustrious ' HibernianPersonalof' is, if possible, more redolent of humour than ever. T h e
getting wp of the piece is unexceptionable, and it
was exceedingly well received."— Weekly Dispatch
HtwM Direct..*, Mr. Re«».

HHBB

PHESS I

" One of the beat Christmas Pieces that h*v»
been produced is the amusing extravagant*
brought out a t the Haymarket, and called
O ' F L A N N I O A N AND T H E F A I R I E S , a d r a m a t i z i n g

of the Irish fairy legend, called, • Hie over to
England.' There are several amusing scenes in
the course of the piece, one of the best being
the fair scene, with a skirmish among the boys,
ending with not a few broki u hands. It were,
p e r h a p s needless to sa~ that, i.s to Power was
entrusted the task of delineating the peculiarities
«f a light-hearted
and light-headed broth of a
boy, he acquitted himself of his task, and t h e
piece was given out for repetition without a dissentient voice,"—Court Journal.
" The prin cipal attraction at this theatre, on
Wednesday, was the fairy piece, O ' F L A N N I O A N
AND T H E D A I R I E S , in which Power weutthrough
the part with his usual buoyancy of spirit, a n d
produced shouts of laughter by his drolleries as
the unfortunate Phelim O'Flannujan.
T h e piece
has been well got up, and does infinite credit to
the management."—The Aye.
" On Wednesday night, a piece, entitled O*
F L A N N I G A N A N D T H E F A I R I E S , dramatized from

a collection of Irish Fairy Tales.after the fashion
of 'O'Rourke and the Eagle,' was produced with
great success. This piece is grounded upon t h e
drunken adventures of O'fVa-.towKMr.PowER)
who, in his potations, wanders among the fairies
on the eve of his marriage ; and his frolics among
the ' good people,' although not exactly in the
manner of Titania, Obtron and Bully Bottom, are
irresistibly ludicrous.
Mrs. F I T Z W I L L I A M , a s
Marif his 'intended, looked, acted, and sang very
sweetly, and the house was in a roar from the commencement till the fall of the curtain."—Atlas.
" Mr. P O W E R , in a tale of the Irish fairies,
embodied all the humours and was a fit representative of all the gladness, that are peculiar to the
season.

O ' F L A N N I O A N A N D T H E F A I R I E S , an

excellent vomicromance by Mr. P O W E R himself,
will no doubt-have a most successful holiday run."
—Examiner >
" POWER is the life and soul of the fun; how
he breaks his vow of tee-totalism and temperance,
(in the use of the shilelagh,) and dreams a dream
full of grotesque horrors, and is transported to the
clones in a donkey-cart.
T h e ' fight' and the
•jig' would be alone worth seeing, were there
nothing else to be enjoyed."—The Spectator.
" O ' F L A N N I G A N A N D T H E F A I R I E S is co-

mio in the highest degree, and with the aid of
singing, jigging,fighting, and fairy fun, we doubt
not that P O W E R ' S Phplim O'Piannigan will have
a most successful holiday run."—Post and Sun,
"

Here P O W E R was the Pantomime, ill

0'FI.ANNIGAN

AND T H E F A i i t i E g ; a n d if to

keep a house in roars of laughter, for a whole
evening, be a test of success, we may say that
never were Harlequin, Columbine, Clown a n d
Pantaloon, rolled into one more effectually."—
Literary Gaxetit:
"O'FlANNIGAN

AND T I I E F A I R I E S

isa

vehicle for Mr P O W E R ' S inimitable Irishisms,
whimsicalities, and comiealities,whieh render him
the best delineator of lnw Irish character extant.
' T h e piece was very laughable, and the dialogue
was occasionally relieved by a grotesque dance,
an Irish j i g , or a familiar and pleasing Irish
melody, which excited considerate, applause.
The piece was announcerffor repetitldn without a
single dissentient voice." - MerningMemMSfGlobe
" All the fun of the piece, which is of a
most extravagant and bustling character, rests
upon the shoulders of our inimitable friend, Mr.
P O W E R . In a word, the audience were kept in a
roar of laughter from the very outset to the final
fall of the curtain, and the piece was given ottt
for repetition every evening amidst a timed*!* of
applause.—Chronicle.

r There ii hardly a lonely * alley or wild mountain range in ail trtinm'.. that tsnot eharactrri|«l b r names «ieu»ttnff tier se*td*uc«, or flauttt of the " ttoo»
a m , • » -Atatea," and tba beUef that t h a t . rt£n inhabitants of earth ami air occasionally condescend to intet fere with mortals, either in mirth or!» wafare,
aatll Uoarers atnoogst the peasantry, one of the most poetical of our national superstitions, and highly congenial to the temperament of an imaginative people.
This Drama, however, presents the " G o o d People" in dream only, the action of the piece, from the time the fairies appear, until the steeping O'Flanolgeo
DWBKM once more to a working day world, existing only 1ft the creations of a wild fellow's brain tired by sihlskey. and disordered by hard blows, lata
tsMsginary perils and sufferings being at once the consequence of his intemperance, nnd the moral punishment of the relapsed whiskey torer.

CONCERTS a la MUSARD,

Mr.

P OW

Having fur the whole of this week been confined to Ins bed by l . vera fever, and only leaving it
to a t t . n d the performances at night, ham had no opportunity of rehearsing the novelties announced.
Iu order that the Public may not experience the slightest disappointment, Mr. P O W E R ha* therefor,
renewed hi* engagement for

SIX NIGHTS MORE,

Postponing his Benefit until M O N D A Y , May the 27th.

SINGLE LIFE!

As the Comedy ot • HIARRIED LIFE* attempted to illustrate a few of
the humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever ; the author of* SINGLE LIFE*
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters *LOTGllS
ALL,* hope, to be equally successful in pourtray ing some of the vagaries
•r Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has i t .
bickering, as w ell as the most loyal one of * The United States.*

ALL,* hopes to be equally successful in pour t raying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and sho wins that the demoeratle region of celibacy has i t .
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of' The United States.*

n original Comedy m Three Acta, by Mr B u c s r o H E , called

As the Comedy ot * MARRIED LIFE* attempted to Illustrate afewof
the humours of the State Matrimonial, and Interest an audience without
the introduction of any I,«vers whatever ; the author of* SI NCrLE LIFE*
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters 'LOVERS
ALL,* hopes to be equal ly successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and sho w ins that the democratic region of celibacy has Its
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of* The United States.*

Will be performed ( F I F T H T I M E ) .

original Comedy in Three Acts, by Mr BUCKSTONE, called

SINCLE LIFE!
As the Comedy ot« H a R B I l B LIFE* attempted to illustrate a few of
the humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever • the author of* SINGLE LIFE*
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters * LOVERS
ALL,' hopes to be equally successful in pourtrajring some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickering, as weU as the most loyal one of • The United States.*

BACHELORS.
I Mr. John Niggle,
(afluctuatingBachelor)
Mr. WEBSTER,
Mr* J>avid Damper,
(a Woman-hating Bachelor)

" original Comedy in Three Acts, i>y Mr. BUCKSTONK, called

SINGLE LIFE!

As the Comedy ot * M VIUU El» LIFE! * attempted to illustrate a few of*
the humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever ; the author of* SIN*KLK LIFE*
in going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters 'LOVERS
ALL,' hopes to be equally successful In pourtraytng some of the vagaries
of Ceufpnip. and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has lta
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of * The United States,*

O P I N I O N S of the PUBLIC P R E S S .

" Sir E. L.
• •BOLWRR
- i " iobtained
- » » a "new
i -triumph
a
-••*-•
last night,
-*•and
am-bs*
in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called THE SEA-CAPTAIN, or 1 HE BIRTHRIGHT,
is certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm w;th delight at the performance, we can
hardly sue any end to its atliartion. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the same rlass, and shews
extraordinary resources, ami a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less ihtn the town
on the happy result of the experiment of list night; for we
might rest satisfied w.th the possession of the faculty to produce
such a play, hut the loss to lite public, if be did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is m ire irue than Ihe HI -X in, that, let a
man be wanted ill any given circumstances, tl at man will le
found. Oat National Urtri a waned an author like Bnlvver, and
he stood foiward to g v n new vigour ami animation. All the
performers well deseiv d ihe strongest testimony to their.rxeellenoi-. We cannot pr
d t" go through the differ*uI scenes s*d
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. 'Ihe conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which ran convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excit-d, and the suspense carried on, almost 10 the
termination of the drama. The writ ng is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the sise of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears te be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remeuiber when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations ,• but We
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance at
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
toauihor, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
««Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scsne in the Fourth Art, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was safe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
—Times, Not. In.
" Last night, was produced Sir E, l.. Bulwer's new drarmt'Of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN, or THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when the * drop fell,' to speak with something like
* execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening until further nstice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiiul than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fine a study of the part as the part would
allow; soma of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—M-rmng Pott.
" The announcement ot Sir E. Lytion Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHH1GHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
he the height ol injustice to deny that, as a lbs. ncal representation, us triumph last night was complete. In the third and fotiHh
acts the enthusiasm of tlie audience rose with th tut-rest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audteuce seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the .whole of the dramatis
persona were calltd forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during the progress of the performance."— Courier*
" Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast ot
characters every way calculated to do a pices justice. The
story is well worked out; Marready's part was especially well
suited t* him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. 1. Webster gave out th« play for repetition * every evening
tilt further notice' amidst the loudest ami most genera! applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting play, abounding in what are
technically termed "good situations,''—G obe, Nov. 1, 1839.
" A new live Art Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAP't AIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is [aid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His scene with his mo'her, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. Mte denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he goes to Ihe
hearth, and invokes his ancestors to hail their son—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublimity itself. He was called for at
the conclusion, as were Mrs Warner, Miss H. f'aucit, and Strickland. The Play was given out for repetition even Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—,S'«».
" W e stated yesterday that the new ph.y of Sir Edward lyltrni
Bulwer, entitled T H E SKA-CAPTAIN J or, THE BIR'lNBIGH T, had been produced at this tluatre on the pretimis eiening, and that it had met with complete success. It is truly
contemptible teobaerve with what feeling and acumen the rjoii'tic$U bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made subservient in their respective notices of this new play; as thoujih
playright and politician were synonymous terms, and the drama a
toere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the ' Birthright' been known only as a dramntir auth >r, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the drama
in question ; hut we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what you .like) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as difficult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
politics. These strict ores, nioieowr, (whose nbservanet of party
unanimity is wonderful, araf whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustre of literature,
and advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly bless our stars that no such dictates govern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, th<
* Birthright' is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in Ihe poetic beauties with which his writings arc known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play^ of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the. part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in Ihe performance; and we have no
g-ubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The house is crowded nightly.—Shipping Gazette, i\'s».2,
" T H E SEA-CAPTAIN, or IHE BIRTHRIGHT, has more
the character of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer; and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, fetter acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, secured its triumphant success."—Examiner.

B F Play,
. . THE
•-•w
e - s - n - i s - l ^ - . s s; - or,
'l,
S i r Lytton
Bulwer's
SEA-CAPTAIN
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and genera) presentment of the Play
are ol kindred excellence' The scene in the Old Hall, with its
carved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
A rundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen for many a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching simiHtui es. It will doubtless be extremely popular."-—Belle Life in
ho>< don
" On Thursday, Sir E. L. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. itisaDrarjm
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. • Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, wo suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pen of Sir E. L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SUA-CAPTA1N, was produced on ThHrsday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."—Weekly Dispatch, Arb». I.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a n>w triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attrac*ion. It is of a character entirely different from bis three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writingis bold and vigorous. '—Bell's Weehly Mestenger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bnlwer, was produced at this theatre j and,
affording Mr. Macready some fine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a mister of human 'motions
and passions, it wa? very successful."—New Bell's
Weekly
Messenger, JVof 3 , 183».
•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. I.ytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before Ihe curtain rose the house was
crammed to the roof. They reuiemliered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before tbem on the stage a constellatiou of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third ; but
in the fourth, this stalely stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one cf the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house ; and Sir E. Lyttou Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—r-fj'-a.
" S i r E . L . Bulwer's new Plaj of THE 8EA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
hereon, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject hiin, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market ; and the costunics are appropriate and splendid."—Alhcnirum.
" A new Play entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE
1 IR ! IIKIGH1, was produced here tin Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter is often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr. Marread, to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
— The Argut.
The little Theatre, as it is still termed, through habit, though
net so little either, was crowded in evety part on Thnrsday
»i tiling, by an audience anxious to assist at the first rt.presentatirn of Sir Edward Lylton Bulwer's new play of The SEA-CAP•i U N ; or, The B l k T H R l G H T . The play was rapturously
n i rived by the audience, and will have what is technically called
a run.
It is equal in poelic beauty and originality of "thought
to the " tjidy of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—John Bull.
'• Sir Edw. Lytton Bulwer's niw play. The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first time at this theatre ou Thursday
list. The success was unequivocal and complete.
. . . .
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
vw have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such ;>s liulwercao write. In the march of his plot Ihe author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act terminating with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
imp it all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throughout was tine to perfection."—Court Journal.
" Sn E. Lyfton Bulwer may well laugh al newspaper criticism,
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning

B] sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny

O P I N I O N S of the FUBCEC P R E S S .

•* S i r E . L. BUI.WRR obtained a new triumph last night, and
in e»ery respect it is likely to be a tasting tnumph. Ilia new
drama, called Th« SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, I HE BIRTHRIGHT,
ia eertain of a long ran ; and coming immediate!? from the representation, and warm w^th delight at the performance, we ran
hardly s e any end to its attraction. It ia of a character entira y
different from his three other works of the same class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a rersatitity of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
might rest satiified with the possession of the faculty to produce
such a pl.iy, but the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
be irreparab'r. Nothing is m -re true than the in xuti, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, tl.at man will Vefound. Our National I'runia waned an author like llnlwer, and
he stood I'm ward to gite it new visour ami animation. All the
performers well deserted the strongest tretimouy to Heir excell e n c . We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations ol this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of ihe most stirring and animating scenes
ws remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even s taint notion of
Ihe interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama The writing is bold and rigorous, and
in s theatre the sise of the Hay-Market it ia not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered ia the wider area of a large
theatre. Ws do not remember when we have sat ont a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drams. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
Jo author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
\ - Sir K, L. Bnlwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Art, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
wasaafe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly "
—Tro.es, Not. Ut.
'
«' Last night, was produced Sir B . I.. Bulwer's new drama of
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN | or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when t h e ' drop fell,' to speak with something like
' execution,' there were shout, of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true snd beautiful than any that.
are to h- <••-<nl tn IBs author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fines stndy of the nan as the oart would
«Uow; some of his declamation' - « • oA«P>W, M,«x?.'iJ*!;l™«]*
waTrtn, powerful, eiRigcti.. The passage where Norma* - , . , , ,
his slatms before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, diaw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning Pott.
" The announcement ol Sir E. Lytton Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E 8EA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHH1GHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, Us triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth
acts ihe enthusiasm of the audience rose wiih the iuttrest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by tbeir feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatis)
firrtonir were called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during Ihe progress of the performance."—Courier.
" Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, wsa brought out last night with a cast of
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well worked out; Macresdy's psrt was especially wall
suited t* him, and we have rarely seen him lo greater advantage.
Mr. 3. Webster gsve out the play for repetition ' every evening.
till further notice, amidst the loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting play, abounding in what are
technically termed 'good situations."—Glebe, Ntt. 1, 1839.
« A new live Act Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAtN; or, T H E B I R T H RIGHT, was produced at this Thestre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Eliza.
belli the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His scene with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him lorth—he goes to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestors to hail theirson—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublimity itself. He was called for at
thtusonclusion, as were Mrs.Warner, Miss H. Paucit, and Strickland! The Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sttn.
" We stated yesterday that the new play of Sir Edward I.ytion
Bolwer, entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIR I HR1GH I'. had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, snd that it had met with complete success. It is truly
contemptible lo observe with what feeling and acumen the political bias of our contemporaries of the daily press w made subservient in their respective notices of this new plsy; as though
playright aud politician were synonymous terms, and the drama a
mere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the ' Birthright' been known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the drama
in question ; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what youlike) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as difficult to form sn opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
umuiioutf is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustte of literature,
and advantage less the cause of the drama. Bat enough. We
may quietly bless our stars that no such dictates govern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
« Birthright' is mere replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less.
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of strik ing power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in the performance; and we haye no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The bouse is crowded nightly."—Skipping Gazette.
* - « THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, has mote
* the character of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer; and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which, is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, secured its triumphant success."—Examiner.

Lytton Bulwer's new Play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN . or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Phi
are ol kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with ita
carved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening lo the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen formsny a day. The Plsy abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touchiug similita e*. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—BeU't lAte in
Lm-don
" On Thursday, S i r E . L. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAP.
T A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. I t i . a D r s m a
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak ia unqualified teuns. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is Isid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberal,
ity, has brought out a new play, from the pes of Sir R. L. Bnlwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permsnent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulw„r's new play. THE SEA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."— Weekly Ditpatvh, Not. 1.
" S r E. L. Bulwer obtained a n-w triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, snd wsrm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attrac'ion. It is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writing is bold and vigorous. '—Belle
Weekly Messenger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Macready some fine opportunities for the manifestation of bis unrivalled power as a master of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful.*—New Bell'e
Weeklu
Meuenger, Not 3 , 183«.
•' last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Rulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
cramiheil to "the root, they remembered that Bulwer was a sue.
cessful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on Ihe stage a constellation ol talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in ihe third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw, The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house; snd Sir E. Lytton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r F . I . . Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Thnrs.
day, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and be takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
made us forget thst we were at the Hay-Market; and the costutrtes are appropriate and splendid."—Atkenesum.
" A new Play entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE
BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in ploi or language, and ihe latter is often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr. Macready lo greater a»l»a«itBge. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
— 7 * * Argut.
'• The little Theatre, as it is still termed,through habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in every part on Thursday
evening, by »n audience anxious to assis! at the first representation of Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer's new play of The SEA-CAPT A I N ; or, The BIRTHRIGHT. The play was rapt-ronaly
received by the audience, and will have what is technically called
a run.
It is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
to the " Lady of Lyons," or " Richelieu.",—John Bull.
" Sir Edw, l.ytlon Bulwer's new play, The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first time st this theatre on Thursday
last. The success was unequivocal and complete
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
w • have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such m Bulwer can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act terminating with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine to perfection."-—Court Journal.
" Sir E. Lytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism,
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed much more by political feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny
that his new drama, I h e SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
triumphant success, but they did their " little, possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the worthleesness of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not roach mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run, and long even after the first season."—Oistrrer.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, not only
in the haven of love, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias oar
opinions."—Parthenon,
•• Sir E. L. Bnlwer's Play, in Five Acts, called The S E A CAPTAIN; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this
house on Thursday night, and proved highly successful. The
Play was announced for repetition every evening ; aud we have
nodoubt it will draw good houses."—Court Gamette.
" On Thursday, Sir Edward L. Bulwer's play of THE SEACAPTAIN ; or T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here » a .
audience crowded in every part, and with the most unbounded
and deserved success. ' Most deserved,' for both ia action and
poetry it is a noble dramatic production; the plot and leading
characters possessing much originality, and the incidents and
situations turning upon them being, consequently, novel and
effective. Nothing could exceed the success of the whole, and
the management may put on its nightcap for the rest of the
season, w bile the public crowd to have their every mghrs enjoyments of a public drama acted in a masterly style. Trie period is
the Elizabethan age."—Literary Gatettt.

" Sir E. I,.
BULWER obtained a new triumph^ last
night,
and
in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIKTHK1UHT.
is certain of a long run ; and coining immediately from the representation, and warm wUh delight at the performance, we can
hardly s e any end to its attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the same class, and shews
extraordinary resourre*, ami a vetssliltly of power fir which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less ihan the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
might rest satisfied w.in the possession of the faculty i» produce
such a jil.iy, bnt the loss to the public, if h« did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing in m >re true than the in ixmi, ihat, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, tl at titan will Ire
found. Our National drama wan.ee! in auihor like !»ulwer, and
he stood fm ward to give it «•» vigour a ul animation. All the
performers well deseived >he strongest tcsiuuouy to tt'eir excellence. We runnot pretend to go thr nigh the different scenes and
situations of this adinirably-eonstructetf drama. The eoiirlusion
of the fourth Act is one ol the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which ran convey to the reader even a faint uoiion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost 10 the
termination of the drama The writ;ng in bold and vigorous, and
in » theatre the size of the May-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a targe
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a repress n.
tetion of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quouti'ms; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, mast hare afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
•'Sir E . L. Bulwer's new Drama of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The hat Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
-was safe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
—Time», Nov. l»f.
•' Last night, was produced Sir E. U Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when the' drop fell,' to speak with something like
* execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J .
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravoe, confirmatory of complete success. It contain* passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fine a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We bsve no spaee, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It lias been carefully got up, with new
eeenery and dresses."—Morning Post.
" The announcement ol Sir E. Lvtton Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it mould
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, its triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth
acts ihe enthusiasm of tlte audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth j till at length, at the
falling of the curtaiu, the audience seemed completely carried'
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatic
pereonee were called forward in succession, lo receive a repetition!,
of thus, enthusiastic plau.iits, v. Inch had been so liberally bestowed*
•on them during the progress of the performance."—Courier.
" .Sir Edward BuUer's new play, THE SfcA-L'APTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been fur tome time in prepare-,
tion at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast ot
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well worked out; Macready's part was especially well
suited t» him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. i. Webster gave out the play for repetition * every evening
till further notice, amidst the loudest and most genera! applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting play, abounding in what are
technically termed 'good situations.'*—Glolie, /Vs.. 1, 1830.
" A new live Art Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lyttoo
Bulwer, entitled The HEA-CAPT AlN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Normsn. His scene with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he goes to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestors to hail their son—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublimity itself. He was called for at
the conclusion, as were Mrs.Warner, Miss H. Eaucit, and Strickland. The Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" We stated yesterday that the new play of Sir Edward l.ytlnn
Bulwer, entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE B I R I H RIGHT, had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete success. It is truly
cotiteinplibie teobserve with what feeling and acumen the political bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made subservient in their respective notices of this new play; as though
playright and politician were synonymous terms, and the drama a
mere shuttlecock for partisanship. Mad the author of the * Birthright' Wen known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the drama
in question j but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what youlike) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as difficult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
unanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the tustie of literature,
and advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietlv bless our stars that no such dictates govern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
* Birthright' is mare replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in the performance; and we haye no
doubt that the < Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The house is crowded nightly."—Shipping Qwsttte.
. •• THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGH ", has more
the character of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer ; and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, secured its triumphant success."—Bvaminer.
