" WSir
Lytton Bulwer's new Play,
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying lo the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author We rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Pla
are ol kiudred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with its
carved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
Wiu'ifu 1 picture we have seen for many a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching simi*
Ktti w. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Bell's Life in

' " i in Thursday, Sir E. L. Bulwer's Play of T H E SKA-CAPT A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. ItisaDrama
of •n.isiderable interest. Of Ihe acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up of
th Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. * Good wine needs no
bush.' The Hay was given out for every evening until farther
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pes of Sir E. L, Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances bad filled
tile house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play. THE SEA-CAPTAIN, waa produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."— Weekly Dispatch, Not. 1.
" S r E. L. Bulwer obtained a n w triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
ran ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attrac'ion. I t is of » character entirely different from bis three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writing is bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly /Messenger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Balwer, was produced at thia theatre; and,
affording Mr. Macready some fine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a in ister of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful.*'—New Bell's
Weekly
Messenger, Nov 3 , 1839.
•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bnlwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the bouse was
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius ;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second art, and increased in the third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thuuders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house ; and Sir E, l.ytton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his awn powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . t . Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who bad been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the costumes are appropriate and splendid."—Athentenm.
" A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; ot, T H E
l'iI RI'11 R I G H 1 , waa produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter is often very
pretty am) occasionally poetical. We have tardy seen Mr. Macready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
— The Argue.
" The little Theatre, as it is still termed,through habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in every part on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious lo assist at the first representation of Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer's new play of The SEA-CAPT A I N ; or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was rapturously
received by the audience, and will have what is technically called
« run. It is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
to th- " Lady of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—John bull.
*• Sir Edw. I.yttoti Bulwer's new play. The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first time at this theatre on Thursday
last. 1 be success was unequivocal and complete, . . . .
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
«e have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such as Bul* r can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act terminating with a thrilling event, earh suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to Ihe final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine to perfection."—Court Journal.
" Sir E. Lytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism,
seeii-g that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed much more by political feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny
Ihat his new drama, The SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
triumphant success, but they did their *' little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the worlhlessness of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not much mistaken, it w.ll long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run. and long even after the first season."—Oieemer.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, not only
in tile haven of love, but, what is of more consequence la actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor iu the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias our
opinions."—Parthenon.
•' Sir E. L. Bulwer's Play, in Five Acts, called The SEACAPTAIN; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this
house on Thursday night, and proved highly successful. The
Play was announced for repetition every evening ; and we have
uodoubt it will draw good houses."—Oourl Gazette.
" On Thursday, Sir Edward L, Bulwer's play of THE SEACAPTA1N; or THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here to an
audience crowded in every pari, and with the most unbounded
and deserved success. * Most deserved," ( or both in action and
poetry it is a noble dramatic production; the plot and leading
characters possessing much originality, and the incidents and
situations turning upon them being, consequently, novel and
effective. Nothing could exceed the success of the whole, gad
the management may {tut on its nightcap for the rest of the
season, while the public crowd to have their every night's enjoyments of a public drama acted in a masterly style. The period's
the Elizabethan age."—Literary Gazette,

OPINIONS of the PUBLIC PRESS.
. " Sir E. L. BULWER obtained a new triumph last night, and
every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; o r , T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
is certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm with delight at the performance, we can
hardly see any end to its attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the same class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
n i g h t rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
such a plsy, but the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
found. Our National Drama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
he stood fotward to give it new vigour and uuimation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost 10 the
termination of the drama The writing is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the aixe of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember wlten we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beaatiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—.Morning Chronicle.
,B

" Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was safe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
— T i m e s , Nov. 1#(.
«* Last night, was produced Sir E . L. Bulwcr's new drama of
T H E 8 E A - C A I T A l > i ; o r , THE B1UTHH1GHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when lire ' drop fell,' to speak with something like
* execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. 1.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition * every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and braves, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to lie found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fine a study of .the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
vv*rm, powerful, energetic. 'I he passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning /'«*(.
" The announcement ol Sir E. Lytlon Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, beitjg occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, H a theatrical representation, its triumph last might was complete. In the third and fourth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely tarried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatis
persona were called forward in succession, to receive arepetitioa
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during the progress of the performance."— PourtVr.
•' Sir Edward Bulwer'a new play, T H E SEA-CA PTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast ot
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
atory is well worked out; Macready's part was especially well
suiti d to him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. 1, Webstet gave out the play for repetition ' every evening
till further notice, amidst the loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestionably a pood actio; plsy, abounding in what are
technically termed ' good situations."—Gteoe, Nov. 1, 1889.
" A new live Art Play, from the pen of Sir Edward l.vtton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHR I G H T , was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North ot Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His ocene with his mother, where be
makes himself known to her, Wat magnificent. She denirg his
claim, and rails her menials to thrust him forth—he goes to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor, to bail their son—his action, bis
look, his utterance, was sublitni v itself. He was called for at
the/conclusion, as were Mrs. Warner, Miss H. Faucil, and Strickland. The Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the ttuatiimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" W e stated yesterday that the new piav of Sir Edward Lyttou
Bulwer, entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT* had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete success. It is truly
contemptible toobseive with what feeling and acumen lite politieal bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made subservient in their respective notices of this new plav ; as though
playright and politician Were synonymous terms, and the drama a
mere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had (be author of the ' Birthright' been known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the means of
Judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the drama
in question ; hut we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
{or what you-hke) criticisms thus put forth, it vould be as dimcult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between pfays and
politics. These strictures, moreeiver, (whose observance of party
unanimity i» wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustie of literature,
and advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly bless our stars that no such dictates govern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
• Birthright* is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic* beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast ia the performance; and we have tin
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The house ia crowded nightly."—$h%pping Gaeette.
* • * THE BEA-CAPTAlNi or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, has ra»re
tbe character of a romantic play than wa have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer; and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which ia properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, seeared its triumphant sueeesa."—Examiner.

" S i r L y t t o n Bulwer's new Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying to the \utlior, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Pla
are of kindred excellence. The scene in the * * Id Hall, with its
carved pauiiels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to tile sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen formany a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Bell's Life in
London
" On Thursday, Sir E. L. Bulwer's Plav of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN : or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. ItisaDrama
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no eJpence in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elis-nbeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The llay was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."™-Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance, of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pen of Sir E, L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performance had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play. THE SEA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affbrds many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."—Weekly Dispatch, Nov. 1
" Sir E." L. Bulwer obtained a n-w triumph on Thursday
night, and iu every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attrac 'ion. It is of a character entirely different from his throe
* other'works of the 3ame class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared. ,
The writing is bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly Messenger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer, was produced at this theatre ; aBd,
affording Mr. Macready some fine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a muster of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful."—New Bell's

Messenger, Nov 3 , 1839.
" Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Buiwer.
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house was
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius ;
and they saw before them on (he stage a constellation ot talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened io the second act, and increased in the third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, ant! the drop-scene of the act tell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house; and Sir E. Lytton Bulwer. owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r K. L Bulwer's new Play of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theat re, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. Tbe Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, be not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies Ins claim to he
her son, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
bis right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the costurnes are appropriate and splendid."—Athenteum.
" A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
B1RTHRIGH), was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is uo
immorality either in plot or language, and the lattei is often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr. Macready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
—Tne A r g u t .
" The little Theatre, as it is still termed.through habit, though
not so little either, was crowded iu every part on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious to assist at the first representation of Sir Edward Lylton Bulwer's new play of Hie SKA-CAPTAIN ; or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was rapturously
received by tbe andience, and will have what is technically called
a run. I t is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
to the •* 1 ady of Lyons," or ** Richelieu,"—John Hull.
- Sir Edw.Lytton Bulwer's new play. The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first time at this theatre on Thursday
last, '1 he success was unequivocal and complete
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
we have ever seen or heard. .The dialogue is only such as Bulwer can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act ter«
minating with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to tbe final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine to perfection,"—-Court Journal.
" Sir E. I.ytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism,
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed much more by political feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny
that bis new drama, The SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
triumphant success, but they did their " little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by hinting a fanlt here, aad picking
a hole there, to establish the worthlesaness ol popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run, and long even after the. first season."—Observer.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, not only
in the haven of love, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor iu the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias our
opinions."—iParlAenow.

*' Sir K. I., BULWI-K obtained a new triumph last nUht, and
11 every respect it is likely to 're a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-( .'.ITA1N ; o r , 1 HE BIK I HltlliHT.
is certain of a long run ; am! coming immediate!) from the representation, and warm W'th delight at the performance, we ran
hardly s-e any end to its altiaction. It is of a character entire'y
different from hii three oiher works of the same class, and shewg
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power fur which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less ihan the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last nighi; for he
might rest satufied wilh the possession of the faculty to produce
such a play, but the loss to the public, if he did not writ--, would
bt irreparable. Nothing is more, true tl an the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
found. Our National Drama warned a. author like Bulwer, and
he atood fotward to give it new vigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellenee. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Art is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stag*, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writing is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is nut thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations ; but we
most refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning CrVmiuele.

" Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was safe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
— T i m e s , Not. Ut.
*' Last night, was produced Sir E. IM Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded alt
through ; and when the' drop fell,' to speak with something like
' execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition * every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravoe, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infiniMy more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found tn the author's previous dramatic productions.
Maeready made as Hut- a study of the part as tii- part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, ami htv action was
"waarm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to ~ny
more of its merits. It was unequivocally an. cessful, and wilt,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, wilh new
scenery and dresses."—Horning Pott.
" The announcement ol Sir E. Lvttou Bulwer's new Drama,
THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIKTH RIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this bouse last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, its triumph last night wss complete. In the third and fourth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose wilh the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the driimalw
persons were called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
oil them during the progress of the performance."— Courier.
" Sir Edward BuUer's new play,THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast of
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well wirked out; Macready's part was especially well
sutttd to him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. J. Webster gave out the play for repetition ' every evening
till farther notice, amidst the loudest and most g-neral applause.
It is unquestionably a &ood acting play, abound ng in what are
technically termed 'good situations."—Globe, Nor. I, 1830.
" A new live Act Play, from lire pen of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a ueaitr
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macresdy has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His -.cene with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was niigiiihrenl. She deuns hlin
claim, and rails her menials to thrust him lorth—he gars to the
hearth, and invokes ln> ancestor! tn hail iht-irson—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublime y itself. He was called 'or at
the conclusion, as were Mrs.Waruer, Miss H. Fsucit, and Strickland, "the Play was given nut for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one ol the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" W e stated yesterday that the new piny of Sir Edward I vtlon
Bulwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIR I HRIGHT. had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete success. It is truly
contemptible laobserve with what feeling and acumen the fWr'dcoi bias ol our contemporaries of the daily press i« made subservient in their respective notices of this new play; as though
play right and politician were synonymous terms, and the drama a
mere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the au'hnr of the " Birthright' been known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, through (he press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the drama
in question ; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what you like) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as difficult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
unanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
it to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustre ot literature,
rod advantage leiss the cause of the drama. But enough. We
. may quietly bless our stats that no such dictates govern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare jruide our pen. As a diainn, the
'Birthright' is more replete wilh variid and exciting interest ili.n
either of the authir's lormer productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His roioplion and action of tht part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire east in th« performance; and we hat e no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The house is crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazette.
t, •" THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, has more
the character of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of t i e writer; aud, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
U could possibly have bees at any other place, secured its triumphant success."—Examiner.

"• t Lytton Bui wers new Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; o r .
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant succe«. Adjflling more enthusiastic (we will not sajr
general) and gratifyingT$ the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success.
which attended its production. The acting of all the character.
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Pla
are of kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with i t .
carved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, ami
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen for many a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."-—SeW* Life in
London" On Thursdsy, S i r E . L. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced, ItisaDrama
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expense in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—th« dresses
and appointments are also equally correct, ' Ctood wine needs no
buah,* The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age,
" The Hay-Markei, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pee of Sir E. L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursdsy night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."— Weekly Di*pateh, Not. I .

•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, aud before the curtain rose the house wa»
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. Tb*
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-seem* of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one if the most successful pieces we
ever saw, The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house ; and Sir E. Lyiton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as lo his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . L . Bulwer's new Phrv of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with au enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Anoilnr Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
hei e*4L and be takes his stand on bis paternal hearth, and asserts
lii * right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's * Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and.
ni.ide us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the cos*
tumes are appropriate and splendid."— Atheneeum.
" A new Play entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
BIKTHKIGH I , was produced here on Thursday night, with success We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter is often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr. Mac.
ready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."

-' Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays

" Sir E. Lyttou Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism,
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed much more by political feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny"
that his new drama, The SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
triumphant success, but they did their " little possible," to showthat it was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the worthlessness of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are.
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—w*
mean long after the first ran, and long even after the first season,"*—(tystrver.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, not only
in the haven of love, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, r l s safely at anchor in the good graces of
the public We are not of those who admit politics to bias our
opinions."—Parthenon.

O P I N I O N S of the PUBLIC FRESf..
" Sir E. L. BUI.WEE obtained a new triumph last night, and
every respect it i« likely to be a lasting tnumpb. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
M certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm with delight at the performance, we can
hardly see any end to ita attraction. It is of a character entirely
different frsm his three other works of the same class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which »i
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
night rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
such a play, but the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
he irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
n a n be wanted in a»y given circumstances, that man will be
found. Our National Drama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
he stood foiward to give it new vigour and animation. All the
performera well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
•f the plot, which ean convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writ;ng is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a l«rge
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the refle«i«n, thut our readers will have mure (tetlgiii when they witness the performance of
this beantifnl and well-constructed .'iraina. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.

" Sir E. L, Bulwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece~lhe point, which once doubled, all
waasafe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
—Time*, Nov. lit.
" Last night, was produced Sir E, I.. Bulwer's new drama of
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when the ' drop fell,' to speak with something like
'execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening tuitil further notice," amid plenty of applause
and braves, confirmatory of complete .access.
It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fine a study of the part as the part would
allow ; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
wstrm,.powerful, energetic. The passage where iVi'Tinon asserts
his elaims before bis guilty mother and Lord Arnndel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning Poll.
" The announcement ol Sir E. Lytton Bulwer's new Drama,
THESKA-CAPTAIN; or, THE HIRTHIt 1GHT, drew an oversowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the. height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, its trinmph hist night was complete. In the third and fourth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling nf tl,r cuiturn, the audience w i n e d completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatic
persona were called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which bad been so liberally bestowed
on them daring the progress of the performance."—Gtmrier.
•' Sir Edward Buyer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been lor tome time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast ot
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well vvi rked out; Maeready's part was especially well
suite (1 to him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. i. Webster gave out the ploy for repetition • every evening
till further notice, amidst the loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting play, abounding in what are
technically termed 'good situations."—Globe, Nov. 1, 1839.
" A new Hve Art Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN • or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His ucene with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
«laim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he goes to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestori to hail their son—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublimi y itself. He was called for at
the conclusion, ss were Mrs.Wsrner, Miss H. I'aucit, and Strickland. The Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" W e sated veMert'ity that the new play of Sir Edward I.ytton
Bulwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, had been predict d at this tin litre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete success. It is truly
contemptible teobseive with what feeling and acumen the/.o/i/i«d" bias of our i tutenipornries of the t>aily press is made subservient in their rtspectite notices of this new play; as though
pleyright aud.politirian Were synonymous terms, and the drama •
asere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the * Hirlhright' been known only as tt dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, throi gh the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or mtrits of the drama
in qutstion j but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
jor what yott-like) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as dimcult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of partyunanimity is wonderful, at d whose tendency, thus distinguished,
it to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustre of literature,
afnd advantage less the cause of the dtama. But enough. We
may quietly bless onr stars that no such dictates govern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
* Birthright* is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which bis writings are known to
abound. Mr. Mscready baa many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were a l l .
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in tin performance; and we baye no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, front its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
atage. The house is crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazette.
t " THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, has more
the character of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer; and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which is property claimed for the machinery el action and movement by the tomsntic atage, lis effect i»
unquestionably great auu powerful. The play, better acted than,
it eonld possibly have been at any other place, secured its triumphant saccate."—S&ammer.

" S i r Lytton Bulwer's new Play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN • or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
-.riumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
jeneral) unci gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Pla
are of kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with ita
sarved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Areudie and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen formany a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situatipns; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Belt* Life in
London
"OnThursday, S i r E . I.. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, wasproduced. ItisaDrama
of considerable interest. Of the acting we car. speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the gatttug up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keepiug with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless hove a run."—j4ge.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pe» of Sir E. L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."— Weekly Ihlpatch, Nov. I.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is hkely to lie a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attrac 'ion. I t is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the 3ame class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writing is bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly
Meilenger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lyttou Bulwer, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Maeready some tine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a master of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful."—,rVfu> Bell'i
Weekly
Meiienger, Nov 3, 1839.
•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the bouse waa
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond alt question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one cf the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house ; and Sir E. Lytton Bulwer, owiug as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, lias achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his getav*,"'— Era.
" S i r E . L. Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was broughtout at this Theatre, on Thursday, end met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and be takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and assert?
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,* is beautiful, and
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the costumes are appropriate and splendid."—ithmmum.
" A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, end the lattet is often verv
pretty ana occasionally poetical. W e have rarely seen Mr. Macready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
— The Argui.
" The little Theatre,as it is still termed,through habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in every part on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious to assist at the first representaticn of Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer's new play of The SEA-CAPT A 1 N ; or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was raptnreusly
received by the audience, and will have what is technically called
a r u n . It is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
to the " lady of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—John Bull.
" Sir Edw. Lytton Bulwer's new p ^ y . The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first lime at this theatre on Thursday
last. The success was unequivocal and complete,
. . . .
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
we have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only sueh as Bulwer can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act ter.
minuting with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
imp.rt ail opinion as to ihe final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine to perfection."—Co«rf Journal.
" Sir E. I.ytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism,
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
lournals have been governed much more by political feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny
that his new drama, Ihe SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the moat
triumphant success, but tbey did their " little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the worthlessness of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run, and long even after the first season."—Ooaerwer.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to Say, arrived safe and sound, not only
in the haven of love, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias our
opinions."—Parthenon.
" Sir E. L. Bnlwer's Play, in Five Acts, called The 8 E A CAPTA1N; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, waa produced at this
house on Thursday night, and proved highly successful. The
' Play was announced for repetition every evening; and we bavuodonbt it will draw good houses."—Court Gazette.
•' On Thursday, Sir Edward L. Bulwer's phty of THE SEA
CAPTAIN; or T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here te ai
audience crowded in every part, and with the moat uoboundei'
and deserved success. " Most deserved,' for both in action «M*
poetry it is a noble dramatic production; the plot and leadinj
characters possessing much originality, and the incidents and
situations turning upon them being, consequently, novel and
effective. Nothing could exceed the success, of die whale, and
the management may put on it* nightcap ter the rest of »be
season, while the public crowd to have their every aigAtV enjoyments of a public drama acted in a masterly style. The p e r M : *
the Elizabethan age."—Liternry Get)

OPHUXORIS of E_t_.it p t f R L I C PS LEI

•' Sir E. L. BotWER obtained a new triumph last night, and
i s every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT,
is certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm with delight at the performance, we can
hardly see any end to its attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the same class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate htm less than the towu
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
•night rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
such a play, but the loss to the public, if h« did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
found. Our National Drama wanted on author like Bulwer, and
he stood foiward to give it new vigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act it one of the most (.lining and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
«f the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
itTO.;„«(,„,, „f the drama. The writjng is bold and rigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the H»y-ttark»t it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wirier urea ofa large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space fur a few more quotations,- but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, thdt our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and nell-rouslrucled drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
«• Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the poiut, which once doubled, all
was safe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
— Times, Nov. l»(.
" Last night, was produced Sir E. L. Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when the' drop fell,' to speak with something like
' execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr, J.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition * every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It coniains patsagea of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fine a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, wan
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up. with new
scenery and dreases."—Morning Pott.
" The announcement ol Sir E. I.ytloii Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drewan overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors vt ere opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to den) that, as a theatrical representation, its triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth; till at length, at the
falling'of the curtain, the audience seemed, completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the drrnnatitt
permtHK were called forward in succession, lo receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which bad iieen so liberally bestowed
on them during the p.u,;.,.... -*• .u- ,.-*_»«_,...... Courier
" Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, T H E S E A - t A M ' S f t T ; . . .
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast ot
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well worked o u t ; Macready's part was especially well
suited to him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. 1. Webster gave ont the play for repetition • every evening
till further notice, amidst the. loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting nl»y, abounding in what are
technically termed 'good situations.*'—Globe, Nov. 1, IS80.
" A new five Act H a y , from the pen of Sir Edward Lyltou
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHR I G H T , was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His i,ceue with bis mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her mentals to thrust him tortli—he goes to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor i to hail their son—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublimi'y itself. He was called for at
the .conclusion, as were Mrs. Warner, MissH. Faucit, and Strickland. 'I he Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" We stated yesterday that the new plav of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete success. I t is truly
contemptible teobserve with what feeling and acumen the politicml bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made subservient in their respective notices of Ibis new play; as though
playright and politician wrrr synonymous terms, and the drama a
mere shuttlecock for partisanship. "Had the author of the «Birthright' been known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably hsve been afforded, through the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the drama
in question ; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what yon-like) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as difficult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
polities. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
unanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustie of literature,
(hid advantage lest the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly bless our stars that no anch dictates govern our
thoughts,, or tyranny dare guide oar pen. As a drama, the
' Birthright' is mare replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularise. His conception and action of the part were all
the! rpuld be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in the performance; and We have no
doubt that the • birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic newer, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The bonae is crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazette.
•• THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, has more
the character of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the' writer; »nd, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any ether place, aeenred ite triumphant success."—Examiner.
________

" S i r Lyfton Bulwer's new Piny, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Tburtdsiy, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery anil general presentment of the Pla
are of kindred excellence The scene in the Old Hall, with its
carved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen tormany a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Belt* Life in
London
" On Thursday, Sir E. L. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAPT A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. It is a Drama
of considerable interest. Of the acting we car. speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting «p of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elisabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Piay was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a nm."—Age.
" The Hay-Markei, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pen of Sir E. I.. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had tilled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SKA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."— Weekly Dispatch, Nov. 1.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
rim ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attrac tion. It is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resource*
and a versatility of power for which we were not fufiy prepared.
The writing is bold aud vigorous."—Bell* Weekly M«**engtr.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, ,by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Maori ady some tine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a tastier of hum-u emotions
and passions, it was very successful."—New Bell's
Weekly
Metttnger,
Nor 3 , 1839.
•' Last Thursday evenings new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house was
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the art fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other bouse ; and Sir E. Lyttos Bnlwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumph, of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . L . Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Thnrsday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, ami assert*
eject" 1innrprWit!s!uP.^ly>ug the menials who had been called to
cipally from Nash's • Old English MauSrWr'-eBerv. taken prin•nade us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the eoei
tunits are appropriate and splendid.'"—Athenaum.
" A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
BIRTHRIGHT , was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter is often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr. Mac.
ready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
— Tht Argni.
" The little Theatre, as it is still termed,through habit, though
not so little cither, was crowded in eveiy part on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious lo assist at the first representation of Sir Edward Lylton Bnlwer's new play of The SEA-CAPT A I N J or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was rapturously
received by the audience, and will have what is technically talk*
a run. I t is equal in poetic beaoly and originality of thought
to the *' Lady of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—John Bull,
•• Sir Edw. Lytton Bulwer's new play, The SEA-CAPTAH*.
was produced tVir the first time at this theatre on Thursday
last. The success was unequivocal and complete. . . . .
*' Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
we have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such ns Bulwer can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
himself to he a perfect master of dramatic effect, every net ter«
minuting with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to the final denouement. The acting
throughout was fine to perfection."—-Court Journal.
" Sir E. Lytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper oiticitm,
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed much more by political feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny
that his new drama, The SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the moat
triumphant success, but they did their " little possible," to atww
dial >t was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the worthlessness of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run, and long even after the first season."—Qbtmtr.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, not only
in the haven of love, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bite o_j
opinions."—Parthenon.
