OPINIONS of the PUBLIC PRESS.
" Sir E. L. BeTuWsa, obtained a new triumph last night, and
•" every respect it ia likely to be * lasting triumph. Mia new
drama, ealled The SEA-CAPTAIN ; o r . T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
w certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm w<th delight at the performance, we can
hardly are any end to its attraction. It is of a rharacterentirely
different from his three other works of tile same class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him leas than the town
on, the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
night rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
such a play, bat the loss to the publie, if he did not write, would
bt irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man wilt be
found. Our National Drama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
be stood fotward to give it new vigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writ;ng is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to he when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a represent
tation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations; hut we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beaatiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.

"Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of T H E 8BA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
wasaafe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
— T i m e s , Not. l»f.
" Last night, was produced Sir E . 1.. Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when t h e ' drop fell,' to speak with something like
* execution,' there were shoots of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J .
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repeti.
rion * every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravoa, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fine a study of the part as the part wou'd
allow ; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his aetion was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arunriel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with uew
scenery and dresses."—Morning Pott.
" The announcement ol Sir E . Lytton Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E 8 E A - C A P T A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as thedoors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, its triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatis
ponton it were called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during the progress of the performance."—Courier,
" Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a ca.it ot
characters every way calculated to do a piece jtistire. Tile
atory is well worked out: Macready's part was especially well
suittd to him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. } . Webster gave out the play lor repetition * every eveaiog
till further notue, amidst the loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting play, abounding in what are
technically termed * good situations."—Globe, Nov. 1, 1690.
" A new live Act Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN j or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a ueaier
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His ncette with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he govs to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor i to hail their son—his action, his
look, bis utterance, was siibhtni'y iiself. He was called for at
the conclusion, as were Mrs.Warner, Miss H, Faticit, and Si» t k latul. The Play was iriren cut for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous afplause of oneol the most erowdtd houses
we have ever witnessed."—$un.
" We stated yesterday that the new play of Sir Edward ! yttnn
flulwer, entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE IIIR'lHRIGHT, had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete succe«s. I t is truly
contemptible to observe with what feeling and acumen the po'tttr « ' bias of our contemporaries of the caily pies* is made subservient in their respective notices of this new play: as though
playright and politician were synonymous terms, and I he drama a
•sere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the * Birthright* been known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, through ihe p t o s , the mem- of
judging, in SOUK m iMire,u the charactei Of merits of the dr a a
us question ; but we feel convinced that from the \\ lug or Toty
{or what you like) criticisms thus put forth, it voitli be as diHi.
cult to form an opinion as lo define the affinity lietweeo piav s ,. il
politics. These strictures, moreover, (»hone observance ot party
unanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustre of literature.
drud advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly bless our stars that nonsuch dictates govern our.
thoaghts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
' Birthright* is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
cither of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in the performance; and we have no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The house is crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazette.
*< THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGH I , has more
the character ef a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer ; aud, read or viewed with the
half »f that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, secured its iriumphani success."—Examiner.

" S i r Lytton Bulwer's new Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIM ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
tri umphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not saw
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Pla
are ot kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with ita
carved panne's, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, ami
the picturesqnegroup, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Aruudle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen formany a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations ; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine Hues, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—-Belts Life in
London" On Thursday, S i r E . L. Bulwer's Play of T H E SEA-CAPT A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. I t i a a D r a t m
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run,"—Age.
" The Hay-Market, iu, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pea of Sir E. L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SKA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."—Weekly Dispatch, Not. 1.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph on Thursday;
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and w a r n
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to ita
attrac 'ion. I t is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writing is bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly Messenger,
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Maoready some fine opportunities for (be maaifestatiou of his unrivalled power as a master of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful."—New Bell's
Weekly
Messenger, Nov. 3 , 1839.
•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the hoase was
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the secoud act, and increased in the third ; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house ; and Sir E. Lytton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . L. Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN j or
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was broughtout at this Theatre, on Thural
day, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and be takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally front Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and)
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the costumes are appropriate and splendid."—Athenaum.
" A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter ia often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. W e have rarely seen Mr. Maeready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of apolaus*" "

— The irgui.

" The little Theatre, as it is still termed.through habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in eveiy part on Thursday
event ar, by an audience anxious to assist at the first representation ot Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer's new play of The SEA-CAPTAYN ; or, The BlRTHR1GHT. The play was rapturously
rei eiVed by the audience, and will have what is technically called
a run. It is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
lo the " Lady of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—John Bull.
" Sir Edw.T.ytton Bulwer's new play, The SEA-CAPTAIN,
.was prodaced for the first time at this theaire on Thursday
last. Theiiuccess was unequivocal and complete
. " Such is a hasty sketch of one ef the most charming plays
we have ever seen or heard- The dialogue is only sucii as Bulwef can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
I imself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act far*
minating with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine to perfection."—Court Journal.
" Sir E. Lytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals liar. h*ta governed mu<h more by political feeling than
by sound discretion aim f - j j , d B p e n t . TKey could not deny
that hia new drama, The S E A - C A t * * / u n , j L t - ; . K the most
triumphant success, but they did their '* little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by hiating a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the wi rthlessnees of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
i
much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
in an long after the first run, and long even after the first seasou " — O W r r e r .
" OBThnreday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, not only
in the haven of love, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good grace* of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias our
op i tiions."—Parthenon.
" S i r E . L . Bulwer's Play, in Five Acts, called The S E A CAPTAIN; or, T H E B I R T H K I G H I , was produced at this
house on Thorsday night, and proved highly successful. The
Play was announced for repetition every evening ; and we havr

OPINIONS of the FVBIiIC PRESS.
*' Sirjli. L. BULWEK »•-••-"••-•-»
obtained a new mm
triumph"h*-*.
last night,
VandH
i" every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; o r , T H E BlRTHRHiHT,
is certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm with delight at the performance, we can
hardly si e any end to its attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three, other works of the same class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for ha
might rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
»uch a play, but the loss to th» public, if he did not write, would
bo irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
found. Our National Drama warned an author liki Bulwer, and
he »teod foiward to give i t new \140ur and animation. AH the
performers well deserved the strong**! testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different seenenand
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scene*
we remember on thu stage, but wc despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which ean cfcivey to the reader even a faint notion ot
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writing is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre fi»e sire ot the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a represen.
tation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a f*w more quotations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
wasaafe; and the Sta-Captaiu finished his voyage triumphantly.';
— T i m e s , iVott. ]*(.
" Last night, was produced Sir E. I.. Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through j and wheu the' drop fell,' to speak with something like
' execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J .
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It contain* passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macreidy mnde as tine a study of the part as the part would
allow : some of his declamation was beautiful, ami his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Nvrman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered tor several minutes. We have no space, however, to ?»y
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning Post,
" The announcement ol Sir E. Lvtton Bulwer's new Drama,
THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHK1GHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat nut previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors . ere opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, its triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
failing of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dremalis
persona1 were called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally l»estowed
on them during the progress of the performance."—Courier.
" Sir Kdward Bul*e r 's new play, THE SEA-CAP I A l \ ; BT,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast ot

" A new live Act Play, from the pen of Sir Edward l.ytton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a Bearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Maeready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His ,cene with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he gois to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor) to hail their son—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublimi y itself. He was called for at
the conclusion, as were Mrs.Warner, MissH. Faucit, and Strickland. The Play was given cut for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded house*
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" We stated vesterda) that the new plav of Sir Filwnrd T tttoit
Buhver, entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIR1HRIGHT, had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, mid that it had met with complete niece's. It is trnlv
contemptible to observe with what feeling and ueunieu the Bo/i/icetl bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made Bad*****
vient in their respective notice* of this low play; as though
playngbt slid politician were synonymous terms, and the < roma a
mere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the • Birthright' brcn known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the means nf
judging, in some measure, of' the ciiaracti r or merits of v'*' dran a
in question ; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what you-like) criticisms Urns put forth, it would be as diifi"cull to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
polities. These strictures, moreover, (who.-e observance of pi.ny
unanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguish •!,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustre of literature,
(rod advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly Mess our stars that no snch dictate* goverji our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide onr pen. As a drama, the
* Birthright' is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired, indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in the performance; and we haye no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its interne interest and
dramatic power, keep a king and successful possession of the
stage. The hoase is crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazette,

the chamter of a romantic play than we hare noticed in aiiy previous dramatw effort Of the writer j and, read or viewed with the

*' Sir E . L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm

•' Last Thursday eveniug a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Btslwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house was;
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Butwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage • constellation of talent.
such as could be. produced at 110 other Theatre in London. The:
interest opened in the second act, and increased m the third j bat
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful piece* we
ever saw, Tbe piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in noother house; and Sir E. Lytton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
• S i r E . L Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; o r ,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was broughtout at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where bis obdurate mother denies his claim to be
iter son, and he takes bis stand on his paternal hearth, and assert*:
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called toeject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and.
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market ; and the cos-,
tunics are appropriate aud splendid."—Athenaum.
" A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE.
Bl KTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there 1* no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter i* often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. W e have rarely seen Mr. Maereadi to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause.'*

" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming play,
in have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such as Butwer can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
I irseelf to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act ter.

" Sir E. Lytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed much more by political feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny
that hi* new drama, The SEA-CAPTAIN, iiiet with the most
triumphant success, but they did their " little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
n hole there, to establish the worthlessness of popular approbation. We bold it to be a work of high genins, and if we are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run, and long even after the flret season."'—Observer.
•< QnThursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his fir»t voyage, or perhaps we ought to *ay, arrived safe and sound, not only
ill the haven of love, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in tbe good grace* of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias OWr
opinions."—Parthenon.

O P I N I O N S of t h e PUBLIC FB.BSS.
•< Sir'E. I« BOLWER obtained a new triumph last night, and
in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; o r , T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
is certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm with delight at the performance, we ran
hardly sre any end to its attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the same class, and shew*
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less ihnn the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; fur he
might rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
luch a play, hut the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
fonnd. Our National Drama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
he alood fotward to give it new vigour and animation. All the
performer* well deserved ihe strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
aituations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most alining and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint noiion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost 10 the
termination of the drama. The writing is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market It is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have est out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heariily
wish we had time and space (or a few more quotation* ,• but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
•'Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was aafe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
— T i m e s , Not. 1st.
" Last night, was produced Sir E. L, Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scene* were applauded all
through ; and when the ' drop fell,' to speak with something like
' execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and filially Mr. J.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition • every evening until further notice," amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passage* of poetry infinitely more true aud beautiful than any that
»re to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made a* fine a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Iftrman asserts
his claim* before his guilty mother ami Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have HO space, however, to »ay
more of Us meriis. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning Post.
" The announcement ol Sir E. Lytion Bulwer's new Drama,
THE SKA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not pri viously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, us triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatis
persona were called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of tho»e enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during the progress of the performance."—Courier.
" Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, whrch has been for some time m preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night wilh a cast ol
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. 1 hestory is well wiiktd out; IWurreaily's part was especially well
suited to bun, and we have rarely seen him to greaicr advantage.
Mr. 1. Webster gav • out the play for repetition • every evening
till farther nolne, amidst ihe loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestioinihl) a good acting play, abounding in *|iat are
technically termed ' good situations."—Globe, Nov. 1, 1839.
" A new I ive A< t Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Luton
Bulwer, enntled The MSA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
ialaid in the Berth of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macreidy has added another laurel to his wreath by his beauiilu!.
impersonation of Norman. His .ceiie with hiB mother, where lie
make* himself known to her, was magnificent, fi* denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him torlh—he sots to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor* to hail iheirson—his notion, his
look, his utlerance, was soblimi y itself. He was called tor at
the conclusion, as were Mrs. V\ artier, Miss H. I'aucit, and Str c k land. the Play was given cut for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one oj the most crowd* A houses
we have ever witnessed."—-Swn.
" We stated yesterday that the new piny of Sir Edward 1 vtion
Bnlwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE Hilt IIIRIGHT, had hern produred at this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had mei wilh complete success. It is truly
contemptible loobscive wi>h what feeling and acumen thepo'i'dcil bias of our contemporaries of the c'aily press is marie SI.IIS.Tvient in their rtspcclhe notices ol this new play; as tin ugh
playright and politif lan Were synonymous terms, and ihe drama a
mere »hultlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the ' Birthright' been known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of tin; drama
In question ; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory.
{or what you like) criticisms thus put forth, it v.ould be as difficult to form an opinion as to define Ihe aftiniiy between plays ami
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of partn
unanimity is wondetful, and whose tendency, thus distti.gui.slu'i,
is to the antipodes) will add hut little to the lustre ol literatim-^
srnd advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. W e
may quietly Wess our suns lhat no such dictates govern our
thought*, or tyranny dure guide our pen. A* a drama, the
• Birthright' is more replete wiihvariid and exciting interest Ihan
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macieady has many p»ssag<s m the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither lime nor space now
to particularise. Hi* conception and action of tht part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark isalmost equally
applicable to the entire cast in th« performance; and we haye no
doubt lhat the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
siage. The bouse i* crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazette.
» THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, has more
the cbsTKter of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer; and, read or viewed with the"
half of that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action aud movement by the lomsnttc Mag*-, it* effect is
unquestionably great and powerful, I h e plav, better acted than
it eo*Jd possibly have bees St any other place, steocd lis In*
amphaol success."—Eraminer,

Sir Lytton Bulwer's new Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not sagr
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnewed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
M admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Pis
ar. of kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with it*
curved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, ami
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, i* the most
beautiful picture we have seen formany a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations ; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Bell's life in
London

•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house was
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful riramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
aud they saw before them on the stage A constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third * but
in the fourih, this stately stream of passion aciuiret! the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-seen* of the art lei! amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one cf the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house ; and Sir E. Lyttou Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . L. Bulwer's new Plav of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, ou Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie lhat binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her s> n, and be takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and assert*
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect, The Scenery, taken pritrctpnlly from Nash's ' Old English Mansion*.' is beautiful, and
made us forget lhat we were at the Hay-Market; and the costumes are appropriate and splendid."—Atheneeum*
" A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
111 KTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We thiuk Sir Edward improves aa a dramatis!—there is no

— The Argus,

O P I N I O N S of the PfJBIiIC P R E S S

" Sir E. L. fluiWEu obtained a new triumph l » t night, and
in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
is certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm with delight at the performance, we can
hardly see any end to its attraetion. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the same class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
might rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
such a play, but the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let •
mau be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
found. Our National Drama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
he stood foiward to give it new vigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The Conclusion
of the Fourth Act is bneof the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
»f the plat, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writing is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
" Sir E. L Bulwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was safe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
—TYnse*, Nov. 1st.
. Last night, was produced Sir E. L. Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when the * drop fell,' to speak with something like
* execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J.
Webster was allowed (uloud) to announce the drama for repetition • every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than auy that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as rise a study of the part as the part wou!d
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes* We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally ssccessful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got jip, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning Post.
" The announcement ot Sir E. Lytton Bulwer's new Drama,
THE SEA-CAPTAIN; of, THE BIRTHK1GHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors vvere opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, its triumph lasi iiijjht was complete. In the third and foi.rth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatis
personte were ralhd forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during the progress of the performance."— Courier.
" Sir Edward llulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in. preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with ,< cast of
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well worked out; Marready's part was especially well
suited to him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. J. Welrster gave out the play for repetition • every evening
till further nntue, amidst the loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestionably a {.ond acting ploy, abounding in what are
technically termed ' good situations."—Globe, Nov. I, IS:]!).
"A new live Act Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lylton
Bulwer, entitled The ^EA-CAPTA1N ; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another lauiel to Ins wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His scene with his mother, wheie he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—lie Joes to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor; to hail their son—his action, his
look, his utterance, was subhmi y itself. He was called for at
the conclusion, as were MrsYVariierJMiss II. Iauiit, and Str rkland. 'Ihe Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" We stated yesterday that the new play of Sir Edward I vtfon
Bulwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE H I R I H RIGHT, had been produced at this theatre on the pnvious evening, and that it had met with complete titers**. It is tn.lv
contemptible teobselve wilh vhat feeling at.il act men the^o'Uical bias of our c» nti iiiporaiiis of the r'aily piess i* made subservient in their i-f-ptctne notices of this new play; as though
playright and uoliliiian wer* synonymous terms, and the drama a
mere shuttle'ock for partisanship. Had the au'bor of the ' Birthright' been known only as a dramatic anihor, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits ot'the drama
in question ; but we f*el convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what you-like) criticisms thus put forth, it voubf be as dttricnlt to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
unanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is fo the antipodes) will add but little to the lustre of literature,
jmd advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly bless our stars that no such dictates govern -our
thoughts, 'or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
4
Birthright' is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beanties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of slrik ing power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast i» th« performance; and we have no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The house is crowded nightly ' — &hipfrini> Gazette.
" T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIUHJ, has m»re
the character off a romantic play than we have noticed in anv previous dramatic effort of tl.e writer ; and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which ia properly claimed for the machinery »f action and movement by the lomintir, stag", its effect is
unqnestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at auy other place, secured its triumphant success."—Examiner,

•'Sir Lytton Bulwer'snew Play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN; 01
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thnr»day, wit
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not « .
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. Fo
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the sueees
which attended its production. The acting of all the character
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the' Pla
are of kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with it
carved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, am
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lad;
Arundle and Violet listening'to the sailor's story, it the mo*
beautiful picture we have seen formany a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations ; there are some exquuiti
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching gimi.
litudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Belt* Life in
London
" On Thursday, Sir E . L. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAP.
T A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. ItitsDratw
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee hfs spared no expence in the getting np ol
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with tht
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and vppointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pen of Sir E. L. Bolwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward B n t
wer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."—Weekly Dispatch, Nov. 1.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a n>w triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to he a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of • long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attrac'ion. It is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writingis bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly Messenger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer, was produced at this theatre; aad,
affording Mr. Macready some fine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a master of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful."—New Belt's
Weekly
Messenger, Nov. 3, 1839.
" Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lyttou Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house wai
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius ;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in Loudon. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house; and Sir E. Lytton Bolwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his ewn powers, lias achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . L . Bulwer's new Pla; of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, whfcre his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, take* principally from Nash's * Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the costumes are appropriate and splendid."—Athenmum.
"A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE
HlliTHKIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with sue.
. ess We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
itiimprality "ither in plot or language, and the latter ia often very
pre Hy nid occasionally poetical. We haveiarely seen Mr. Macre idv to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
— The Argus.
" The little Theatre,as it is still termed,through habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in eveiy port on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious io assist at the Prst representation of S T Edward I.ytton Bulwer's new play of The SKA-CAPTAIN ; or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was rapturously
received by the audience, and will have what is technically called
•i n:>.. It is equal in poetic b«>auly and originality of thought
to the «' Lady of Lyons," or *' Richelieu."—John Bull.
" Sir Edw. Lytton Bulwer's new play. The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first time at this theatre on Thursday
last. The success was unequivocal and cunplele.
. . . .
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
we have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such as Bulwer can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act ter»
ruinating with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine io perfection."—Court Journal.
" Sir E. Lyttou Bulwer may well laugh ot newspaper criticism
seetigthut the writers of the articles in the various morning
join itals have been governed muih more by political feeling than
hy sound discretion and fair judgment. They roald not deny
in. i Ins new drama, the SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
triumphant success, but they did their " little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the worthlessness of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run, and long even after the first season."— Oiserver.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to lay, arrived safe and sound, not only
in the haven of Sove, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias our
opinions."—Parthenon.

nodoubt it will draw good houses."—Court Gazette.

OPINIONS of the PUBLIC PRESS.

" Sir E. L. BVLWEK obtained a new triumph last night, and
in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; o r , T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
U certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm w<th delight at Ihe 'performance, we ran
hardly are any end to its attraction. It ia of a character entirely
different from bis three other works of the saute cms., and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of' power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
on the happy reanlt of the experimtnt of last night; for he
might rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
tttch a play, but the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
bund. Onr National Drama wanled an author like Bulwer, and
he stood foiward to gire it new rigour and animation. All the
performers well deterred the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of tile Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
ef the plot, which ean convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writ;ng is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, a .
it often appear* to be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete aatisfaetion. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibW
tion, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
" S i r E . L. Bulwer't new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
waasafe; and the Sea-Captain finished bis voyage triumphantly."
— Timej>. Not). 1»*.
" Last night, was produced Sir E. t.. Bulwer's new drama of
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through ; and when the' drop fell,' to speak with something like
' execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and braves, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the authors previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fine a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and bis action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to Bay
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and wilt,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning Post.
" The announcement ol Sir E . Lytlon Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E SKA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, its triumph last night was complete. In the third and foi.rth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose wilb the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
failing of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatis
persona were culled forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during the progress of the performance."—Courier.
" Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast of
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well w rked out; Maeready's part was especially well
suited to Into, and w-e have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. 3. Webster gave out the play for repetition ' every evening
till furiher notice, amidst the loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting play, abounding in what are
technically termed • good situations."—Globe, Nov. I, 1830.
" A new I ive Act Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled The ."EA-CAPT AlN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. 'Ihe sceue
ialaid in the North of Devon, during the reign ol Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His .'jcene with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he goes to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor* to hail thrirson—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublimi y itself. He was called for at
the conclusion, as were Mrs.Wyrner, Miss II. faueit, and Strickland- I h e Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Svv.
" We stated yesterday that the new play of Sir Edward I ttton
Belwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN . or, THE Bill" I HRIGHT, had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete success. It is truly
contemptible teobseive with what feeling end acumen thepo/i<tcal bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made subservient in their respective notices of this new play ; as though
playright and politician were synonymous terms, and the drama »
mere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the " Birthright' been known only as a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, thriu git the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of (he character or merits of the d rani a
in question J hut we feel convinced that from the \\ hig or Tory
(or whst youlikej criticisms thus put forth, it would he. as difficult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays an*!
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
unanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the luslie of literature,
Aid advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly bless our stars that no sut h dictates got ern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
* Birthright' is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in the performance; and we have no
doubt that the ' Birthright' wit), from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The house is crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazette.
•• THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, has more
the character of a romantic play than we hate noticed in any previous dramatic effort of t i e writer j and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by Ihe romantic stage, lis effect is
unquestionably grett and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, secured its triumphant success."—Examiner.

" S i r Lytton Bulwer's new Play, T H E 8EA-CAPTAIW; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. Foe
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the sonata.
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Play
are of kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with i t .
carved pauuels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centra, by Lads
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
bsauliful picture we have seen formally a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Belts Life in
London« Ou Thursday, Sir E. L. Bulwer's Play of T H E SEA-CAP.
T A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. I t i s a D r a m .
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct, f Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will donbtless have a run."—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberal*
ity, has brought out a new play, from the pen of Sir E. L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bo).
wer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a loag career."— Weekly Dispatch, Nov. 1.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and w a r n
with delight at the performance, we. can hardly see an end to it*
attraction. It is of a character entirely different from his thro*
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resource,
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writing is bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly Messenger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer, was produced at this theatre} s a d .
affording Mr. Macready some fine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a master of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful."—New Bell's
Wetklv
Messenger, Nov. 3 , 1839.
•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E, Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before Ihe curtain rose the house was
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a s u e
cessful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second art, and increased in the. third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed as it can be in no
other house; and Sir E. Lytton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his ewn powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . L . Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was broughtout at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this lime the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' js beautiful, and.
made us forge* that we were at the Hay-Market; and the cos.
tumes are appropriate and splendid."—Athenievm,
" A new Play entitled T H E 8EA-CAPTA1N; or, T H E
BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter is often vers
pretty and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr, Macready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
— The
jrgus.
" The little Theatre, as it is still termed.lhrough habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in eveiy part on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious to assist at the first representation of Sir Edward Lyttem Itulwer's new play of The 8EA-CAPTAliN; or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was rapturously
received by the audience, and will have what is technically called
a run. It is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
to the " Lady of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—John Bull.
" Sir Edw. Lytton Bulwer's new play. The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first time at this theatre on Thursday
la^t. The success was unequivocal and ci mplele
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming plays
we have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such at Bulwer can write. In the march of his plot the author lias proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act t e r .
minating wflh a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine | 0 perfection."—Court Journal.
" Sir E. Lytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism
seeing that the writers of Ihe articles in the various morning
journals have been governed much more by political feeling than
by sound discretion and f»ir judgment. They could not deny
that his new drama, The SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
triumphant success, bui they did their " little possible," to showthat it was a mistake, and hy hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the w o r t h i n e s s of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
Hot much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run, and long even after the first s e t .
son."—Observer.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ooght to »ay, arrived safe and sound, not only
in the haven of love, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias oor
opinions."—Parthenon.
" S i r E . L. Bulwer's Play, in Five Acts, called The SEACAPTAIN j or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this
house on Thursday night, and proved highly successful. The
Play was announced for repetition every evening ; and we haw
nodoubt it will draw good bouses."—Court Gazette.
" On Thursday, Sir Edward L. Bulwer's play of THE SEACAPTAIN ; or T H E ItlHTIlRIGHT, was prodnred here to an

** Sir E. I.. Bu tWE» obtained a new triumph last nipln. and
ia every respect it is likely lo he s lasting triumph. Hi* ww
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; o r , T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
i* certain of a long run ; ami coming immediately from the representation, and warm with delight at the performance, we ean
hardly are any end to its attraction. It ii of a character entirely
different from his three, other work* of the same class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
on the happy result of the .experiment of last night; for he
Bight rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
aaeh a play, but the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will he
bund. Our National Drama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
he s^ood fotward to give It new vigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-cdhstru<**NI drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember ou the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost lo the
termination of the drama. The writing ia bold and rigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations ; but we
mast refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constrncled drama. The whole exhibition, from Hist to last, must have afforded anmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Cftronicl*.

" Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, ell
was safe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
—7V*»e», Nov. 1st.
" Last night, was produced Sir E. L. Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHHIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scones were applauded all
through ; and when the ' drop fell,' to speak with something like
' execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
JKacready made as Sue a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. Thepaasage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we hove no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses,"—Morning Pott.
" The announcement of Sir E. Lvtton Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E SKA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors Were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, its triumph last night was complete. In the third and marsh
acts the enthusiasm of tile audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatis
persona were called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally (resumed
on them during the progress of the performance."—Courier.
" Sir Edward Buyer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been forborne time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last nighi with a cast of
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well w< rked out; Marready's part was especially well
suited ti» him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. J. Webster gave out the play for repetiiion f every evening
till further notice, amidst the loudest and most gnwral applause.
It is uuqutstiouably a good acting play, abounding in what are
technically termed ' good situations."—Globe, AW. 1, I89D.
" A new live Art Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre lust evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day ; a nearer
approach to the unities thsn is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His -icene with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he goes to Ihi
hearth, and invokes his ancestor! to hail their son—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublimi'y itself. He was called for at
the conclusion, as were Mrs.Warner, Miss H. Faucit, and Strickland, "lhe Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed,"—Sun.
" We stated yesterday that the ne« play of Sir Edward l,y tion
Bulwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; o r , T H E B I R I H R1GH Y, had been produced at this thestre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete suece's. 11 is truly
contemptible to observe with what feeling and acumen tin. j .:iitieal bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made subser•lent in their respective notices of this new play; as though
playright and politician were synonymous terms, and the drama «
• e r e shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the ' Birthlight' been knovi u only as a dramatic author, the public would '
probably have been afforded, through the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the drama
In question ; bot we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what youlike) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as difficult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
smanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add bat little to the lustre of literature-,
.ad advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly West* our stars that no such dictates govern out
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
* Birthright" is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passagea in the play, of strik ins; power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in the performance; and we hare no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the
stage. The bouse is crowded nightly."—Skipping Gazette.
- THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE B I R T H R I G H I , has more
the character of a romantic play than w* hava noticed is any prev i e w dramatic effort of the writer; and, read or viewed with the
kalfof that allowance which is properly chimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
aaquestiouably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, secured its triamphant success,"—J&tnsjjWr',
