" S i r Lytton Bulwer's new Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIU; «r,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will sot saw
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the s u e s . ,
which attended its production. The acting of all the character*
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Hay
are ol kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with it*
carved panuels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, awl
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lad*
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the Host
beautiful picture we have seen for many a day. The Play abound*
in strong effects and stirring situations ; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching siasilitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Bell's
Li/sin
London
" On Thursday, Sir E. L. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAP.
TAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. I t k a D r a a w
of considerable interest. Of the acting we car, speak ia unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally Correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given oat for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a ran,"—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, aa exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pea of Sir E. L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances bad filled
the bouse every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
Creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bala
wrr's new play, THE SKA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thau**
d iv night, with decided success. The piece afford* many eMMW
tunities of producing striking effects. We have no dj**|»*nat

" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph sat Thursday

His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, it
net*

" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, fat five acts, by
Sir Edward Lyttoa Bolwer, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Macresdy some fine opportunities for Ut* I
tation of his unrivalled power as a master of banian i
and passions, it was very successful."—New Bell't
Weekly
Messenger, No* 3 , 183b.
*' Last Thursday evening a uew Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house was
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a saecessful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third; bat
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces w*
ever saw, The piece, in fact, was performed as it (as be in no
other house; and Sir E. Lytton Bulwer, owing as much to th«
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . L. Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was broughtout at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. Tree Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies bis claim to be
her son, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and assert*
ha right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject hiui, produced a sinking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Matrket; and the cos*
tumes are appropriate and splendid."—Athrneeum.
" A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with s a e .
cess. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
irerr.oialitv either in plot or language, and the latter is often very
pi 'try and occasionally poetical. W e have rarely seen Mr. Macready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause.'*
— The Argus.
" The little Theatre, as it is still termed,lhrough habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in eveiy part on Thursday
rveall g . by an audience anxious to assist at the first representation of Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer's new play of The 8EA-CAPTA1N ; or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was rapturously
received by the audience, and will have what is technically called
a run.
It is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
to the " lady of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—John Bull.
" Sir Edw. Lyttou Bulwer's new play, The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first lime at this theatre on Thursday
last. The success was unequivocal and cmplete. . . , .
-" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming play*
«e have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such aa Bulwt r can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act ter»
miiiattug with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
impi rt all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throoghont wa* fine to perfection."-—Court Journal.
" Sir E. Lytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed much more by politics! feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny
that his uew drama, The SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
triumphant success, but they did their '* little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by bintiBg a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the wortiilessuess of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an actios; play—-we
mean long after the first run, and long even after th* first sea.
son."—Observer.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, not only
in 'lie haven of love, bat, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good grace* of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias o w
opinions."—Parthenon.

" Sir E. 1... BULWRB obtained a new triumph last Bight, and
in every respect it i« likely to he a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; o r , T H E BIRTHRIGHT,
ia eertain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm w>th delight at the performance, we ran
hardly s»e any end to iU attraction. Jt is of a character entirely
different from hia three other works of the same claw, and shews
extraordinary resources and a versatility of power for which we
ware not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
might rest satisfied with the possession of the faeulty to produce
such a play, hut the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
be irreparabie. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wauted in any given circumstances, that man will be
f»umt. Our National Orama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
he stood foi ward to give it new vigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excellence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
th« interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writing ia bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of th« kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was safe i and the Sea-Captaiu finished his voyage triumphantly."
—Times, Nov. 1st.
" Last night, was produced Sir E. I.. Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN i or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded all
through •, and when t h e ' drop fell,' to speak with something like
* execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and 6ually Mr. ,1.
Webster was allowed (aloud} to announce the drama for repetition • every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found tn the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macready made as fiae a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
wmrm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery snd dresses."—Morning Pott.
" The annmiuvntneet ol Sir E. Lytton Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E S t A - C A P T A1N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the. doors were opened.
Every out anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representation, its triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourtb
acts the enthusiasm of lite audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carrir d
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramah s
persona were called forward in succession, to receive a repHitic n
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowe d
on them during the progress of the performance."—Omrier.
" Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE StA-CAPTAlN ; o, r,
T H E III BTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in prepar; ition at tins theatre, was brought out last night with a cast < it
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. Tl it
atory is well woiked out; Macready's part was especially we ill
suited te hint, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantag e.
Mr. J. Webster gave out the play for repelition ' every evenui ig
till further notice, amidst the loudest ami most gMieral applaus e.
It is unquestionably a good acting pl**y, abounding in what a re
technically leruied ' good situations."—Globe. Nov. I, l$38.
" A new I ire Art Play, from the pen ol Sir Edward l.vtt in
Bulwer, m u l e d The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE HIKTI 1RKJIlT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The see ne
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Eliz abeth— the time orcupied by the action is one day ; a near er
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another lawie! to his wreath by his beautisful
impersonation of Norman. His icene with his mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he goes to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor! to hail their son—his action, his
look, his utterance, was sublitni y itself. He was call"d for at
the conclusion, as were Mrs-Warner, Miss H, Faurit, and Slrickland, 'the Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause ol one ol the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" W e stated yesterday that the new play of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, had been produced st this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete success. I t is truly
contemptible te observe with what feeling and acumen the politic
eat bias of our contemporaries of the daily press i» made subservient in their respective notices of this new play; as though
playright and politician were synonymous terms, and the drama a
mere shuttlecock fur partisanship. Had the author of the * Birthright' been known only as- a dramatic utithor, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the tctsunf of
judging, in some niensuie, t»l the character or merits ol ihe drama
in qnention; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what youlike) criticisms thus put forth, it would be as difficult to form an opiniun as to define Ihe affinity betwesn plays and
politics. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance ot party
unanimity is wonderful, and vrhese tendency, thus distinguished,,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustte of literature,
•nil advantage less the causa of the drama. But euough. We
may quietly bless uur stars that u» such dictates govern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
* Birthright" is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and ia certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were ail
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in the performance i and we haye no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possesion of the
stage. The house is crowded nightly."—Skipping Gaxeltt.
" THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, has more
the character of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer; and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery ef action and movement by the romantic atsge, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, secured its triumphant success."—lixaminer.

" S i r Lytton Bnlwer'snew Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, wife
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not a-r
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. Foe
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the sueses*
which attended its production. The acting of all the charaett-s
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Play
are ot kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with its)
csrved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, ami
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen for many a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—jfeiT* tAfe in
London
" On Thorsday, S i r E . L. Bulwer's Play of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. Itis aDram*
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can apeak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expend- in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with th«
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and .ippointnients are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
hush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pea of Sir E, L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the bouse every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."— Weekly Dispatch, Nov. 1.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obta'aied a new triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to it*
attraction. It is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the game class, and shows extraordinary resources'
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writing is bold and vigorous."—BelF* Weekly Messenger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious jihf, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Macready sorae fine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a master of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful."—Nett Bell's
Weekly
Messenger, Nov. 3 , 1839.
•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E, Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre.. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house was
crammed to fie roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as coold be produced at no other Theatre l a LOIMOA The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third) but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the intpelsmsity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the roost successful pieces we
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed at it ean he in no
oilier house ; and Sir E. Lytton Bulwer, owing at much, to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, ban achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—fcVrJ,
" S i r E . L Bulwer's new Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Thursday, and nttit with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
NonMa relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
Knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies bis claim to be
her son, and he takes his stand on bis paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market j and the co*rf
tumes are appropriate and splendid."—Atktrueum.
" A new Play entitles! THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
111 RTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with suel
cess. We think Sir Edward improves as s dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the hitter is often very
prettj and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr, Mac.
ready to greater advantage The curtain fell on plenty of applause "

— The Argus.

" Sir Edw. Lyfton Bulwer's new play, The SEA-CAPTAIN
* n produced for the first time at this theatre on Thursday*
last. The success was unequivocal and complete.
. . . .
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming "phvvs
we hare ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only such as Bulwer can write. In the march of bis plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act t e r .
minating with a thrilling iteut, each suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine lo p e r f e c t i o n . " ~ C W l Journal.
" S,r E. Lytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism
seeing that the writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed m u « h more by political feeling thsa
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not' dear
thai Ins new drama, The SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
ti uiiipliant success, but they did their " little possible," to show
il .11 it was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the worthlessues. ol popular appror*.
tarn. VVe hold it to be a work of high genius, and if wc are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run, and long even after the first season."—Observer.
" OnThursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his firsl voyage, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, not only

th- pubbc. We ere not of ihuse who admit politics to bias oar
opinions."—Parthenon.

" Sir E. L. BULWEK obtained a new triumph last night, and
in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT,
is certain of a long run; and coming immediately from the representation, and, warm with delight at the performance, we can
hardly see any end to its attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the samp class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
night rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
such a play, but the loss to the public, if lie did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
found. Our National Drama wanted an author like Bulwer, and
ha atood fmward to give it new rigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excelfence. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of (be plat, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writ;ng is bold and vigorous, and
ia a theatre the sice of the Hay-Market it ia not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a larg*
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a represen.
tation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations, but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must bast afforded unmixed gratification
to author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronicle.
" Sir E. L. Bulwcr's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Pourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was safe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly.''
—TSmes, Not). 1st.
" Last night, was produced Sir E, !-. Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THIi BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded ai
through ; and when the 1 drop !- ll,' to <pt-k with something bke
* execution,' there waft {fefejnU of ptansita; and finally Dlr. J.
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition * every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and braves, confirmatory of complete success. It contains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to be found in the author's previous dramatic productions.
Macrcady made as tine a study of the part as the part would
allow; aome of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no space, however, to say
more.of ita merits. It was unequivocally successful, ami will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses."—Morning Pott.
" The announcement of Sir E. Lytton Bulwer's new Drama,
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
be the height of injustice to deny that,'as a theatrical represents*
tion, its triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth
sets the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth ; till at lergth, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
swstv by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the drmmatit
ptrionm were, called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
em tJiem during the progress of the performance."—Courier.
" Sir Edward Buiwer's new play,THE SKA-CAPIA1N ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, winch has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast of
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well worked out; Matready's part was especially well
suited to him, and we. have rarely seen htm to greater advantage.
Mr. } . Webster gave out the play for repetition * every evening
"till farther notice, amidst the loudest alio most general applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting play, abounding in what are
technically termed " good situations."—Glohe. AW. I, 1839,
" A new l i t e Art Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lylton
Rnlwer, eamled The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, wa* produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in tbs North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth the time occupied by the action is one dry ; a nearer
approach to the. unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another lautel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His 'icetie with his mother, where lie
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to throat him forth—he goes to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor) to hail their son—his action, his
look,his utterance, wassubltmiy itself. He was called for at
the conclusion, aa were Mrs.Warner, Miss H. Faucit, and Strickland. The Play was given nut for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applanse of one ol the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sun.
" We stated yesterday that the new play of Sir Edward I.ytton
Bolwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIR 1 HR1GHT, had been produced at this theatre on the previous evening, and that it had met with complete success. It is truly
contemptible to observe with what feeling and acumen the political bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made subservient in their respective notices of this new play; as though
playright and politician were synonymous terms, and the drama a
mere shuttlecock for partisanship. Had the author of the ' Birthright' been known only aa a dramatic author, the public would
probably have been afforded, through the press, the means of
judging, in some measure, of the character or merits of the drama
in question ; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
(or what you-likej criticisms thus put forth, it would be as diffi.
cult to form an opinion as to define the affinity between plays and
polities. These strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
unanimity is wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustie of literature,
and advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly bless our stars that no such dictates govern our
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. Aa a drama, the
* Birthright' is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not less
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known to
abound. Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of strik log power and beauty, which we have neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could be desired. Indeed the same remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cast in the performance; and we have no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from iut intense interest and
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession of the.
stage. The house is crowded nightly."—Shipping Gazette-.
••THESEA-CAPTAIN; or, 1 HE BIRTHRIGHT, has more
the character of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous dramatic effort of the writer; and, read or viewed with the
half of that allowance which is properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect is
unquestionably great and powerful. The play, better acted than
it could possibly have been »l any other place, secured its triumphant success."—JEi?a»n»»er.

" S i r Lytton Bnlwer's new Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or;
THE BIRTHRIGHT,' was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not ass/
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the success
which attended its production. The acting of all the character*
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Play
are of kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hail, with its
carved piranels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, ami
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the most
beautiful picture we have seen for many a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching simi.
litudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Bell'tt Lift in
London" On Thursday, Sir E. L. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAP.
TAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. ItisaDrama
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up o£
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabeth era—the dressesami appointments are also equally correct. «Good wine needs nobush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pes of Sir E. L. Buiwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN, waa produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities of producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."— Weekly Di»pateh, Not. 1.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it ia likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
r u n ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to it*
attraction. It is of a character entirely different from his three
ether works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resources
am:,-. versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The nitingis bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly
Mettenger.
*" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
8ii M v a r d Lyttoti Bulwer, was produced at ihia theatre; a«d,
ar}> rding Mr. Macready some feat opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a muster of human emotions
and passions, it was very successful."—New BHl'f
Weekla
Metsenger, Nov. 3, 1839.
•' Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rose the house wa*
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dramatist, and, beyond all question, a man of genius;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieees wa
ever saw. The piece, in fact, was performed aa it can be in a s
other house; and Sit E. Lytton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his own powers, has achieved by tt
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Bra.
" S i r E . L. Bulwer's new Play of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception. The Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowuing to the Countess, he t o t
knowing at this lime the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's * Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, and
mads us forget that we were at the Hay-Market ; and the costumts are appropriate and splendid."—Alhenmum.
'• A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter is often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr. M»cready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."

— The Arguf.
" The littk Theatre, aa it is still termed.through habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in eveiy part on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious to assist at the first representation of Sir Edward Lylton Bulwer's new play of The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, -The B I R T H R I G H T . The play waa rapturously
received by the audience, and will have what is technically called
a run.
It is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
to the '* Lady of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—John Bull.
" Sir Edw. Lytton Bulwer's new play, The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first time at this theatre on Thursday
last. The success was unequivocal and complete.
. . . .
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the most charming play*
we have ever seen or heard. The dialogue is only sash as Bulwer can write. In the march of his plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act terminating with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtful
import all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throughout was fine to perfection."—Court Journal.
" Sir E.tytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism
seeing that tile writers of the articles in the various morning
journals have been governed murh more by political feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny
that hia new drama, live SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
triumphant success, but they did their " little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, and by hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the worthtessness of popular approbation. We hold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play—we
mean long after the first run, and long even after the first ten.
mis."—(M»erver.
" On Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his first voyage, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, not only
in the haveu of love, but, what is of more consequence to actor,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias our
opinions."—Parthenon.
" S i r E . L. Bulwer's Play, in Five Acts, called The SEACAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHHIGH'I, was produced at this
house on Thursday night, and proved highly successful. The
Play was announced for repetition every evening ; and we have
nodoubt it will araw good houses."—Court Gazette,
" On Thursday, Fir Edward L. Bulwer's play of THE SEACAPTAIN , or THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here to an
audience crowded in every part, and with the moat unbounded
and deserved success. * Most dear rved,' for both in action and
poetry it is a noble dramatir production ; the plot and leading
characters possessing much originality, and the incidents and
situations turning upon them being, corsrqutatly, novel and
effective. Nothing could exceed the saecttu, of the whole, and
the management may put on its nightcap tor the rest of lha
season, w bile the public crowd to rrav<« their every nighft enj<rr«
menu of a pwblic drama acted in a masterly style". The period is
the Elizabethan age."—Literary GnaeUe.

Theatre Hoywf, MMaymMmrket,
OPINIONS of the PUBLIC P R E S S .
" Sir E. I . BOLSTER obtained a new triumph last night, and
in every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph. His new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT,
it certain of a-long run; and coming Immediately from the representation, and warm with delight at the performance, we can
hardly see any end to its attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the saute class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him less than the town
« the happy result of the experiment of last night, fur he
might rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
each a play, hut the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
be irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
man be wanted in any given circumstances, that man will be
f.unrf. Our National Drama waoted an author like Bulwer, and
he stood 101 ward to give it new rigour and animation. All the
performers well deserved the strongest testimony to their excelfeaee. rVe cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The conclusion
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring ami animating scenes
we remember ou the stage, but we despair of giving any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
the interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of the drama. The writing is bold and rigorous, and
in a theatre the size of the Hay-Market it is not thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider area of a large
theatre. We do not remember whf n we hare sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wish we had time and space for a few more quotations,' but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our readers Will bare more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed Iraroa. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
*» author, actors, and audience."—Morning Chronme,

" Sir E. L. Bnlwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
was safe: and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
-—IX»»e*, Nov. 1st.
" Last night, was produced Sir E. !.. Bulwer's new drama of
THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
iteelf was completely succeseful. The scenes were applauded ail
through j and when the < drop fell,' to sneak with something like
' execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr, J,
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening until further notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory ef complete success. It remains passages of poetry infinitely more true snd beautiful than any that
are to be found tn the author's previous dramatic productions.
Mar ready made as fine a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
warm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We have no spare, however, to say
• o r e of its merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery «I,J *.-„»j« %*~M«ming Post.
T H E SEA-CAPTAIN f or, T H E BIRTH l i l c m i , JU— -,,, on,.
flowing audience t« ftris house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opener}.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
i t t h e height of injustice tn deny that, as a theatrical representaion.its triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth
acts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
Play, which was well sustained in the fifth; till at length, at the
falling of the curtain, the audience seemed completely carried
away by their feelings, and nearly the whole of the tlramatis
fttrmmm were called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during the progress of the performance."—-Courier.
" Sir Edward Bulwer', new play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation at this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast ol
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well worked oat; Macready's part was especially well
suited te him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. J. Webster gave out the play for repetition ' every evening
till further notice, amidst the loudest and most general applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting play, abounding in what are
technically termed 'good situations."—Qlooe, Nov. 1, 1830,
" A new Five Act Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The scene
is laid in the North of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one day j a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His ucene with bis mother, where he
makes himself known to her, was magnificent. She denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he goes to the
hearth, and iavokes his ancestor? to hail their son—his action, hit
look, his utterance, was sublimity itself. He was called for at
the conclusion, as were Mrs.Warner, Miss H- Faucit, and Strickland. The Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
are have ever witnessed."—4"t«tt.
" W e stated yesterday that the new purr of Sir Edward I.ytton
Bulwer, entitled THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, had been produced at this theatre on the pravious evening, and that it had met with complete success. I t is truly
contemptible te observe with what feeling and acumen the pr-ftft«*Z bias of our contemporaries of the daily press is made subter9tt*t in their respective notice* of this new play; as though
Uaftiant and yttWebw were synonymous terms, and the drama a
sa*-SBUtaeewk far KsftiaanshSp. Had the author of ihe • Birth.
t i p * * been known otaW »« a Aratnstic author, the pubt.s. vm\i
probably have been afctderf, through the press, the meant of
Judging, in same measure, of the character or merit* at the dtaja*
l - question | but v * feel convinced that from the Whig o r f 8 r y
(or what you-like) crifieitm* thus put forth, it would be a* * « .
cult tn form an opinion at to devhiE the affinity between plvya and
politics. These stricture*, moreover, (whose observance ot fatty
nnamaoitj it wonderful, and Whose tendency, thus dieting rdafardv
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustre of literature,
and advantage less the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly Hess our stars that no such dictates govern oar
thoughts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
" Birthright' is more replete with varied and exciting interest titan
either of the author's former productions, and is certainly not lew
rich in the poetic beauties with which his writings are known fo
abound. Mr. Macready ha* many passages in the play, of strife.
lag power awl b«*»tj, which we neve neither time nor space urn
to particularise. His conception and action of the part were a l
that could, he desired. Indeed the same remark it aim*** equally
applicable to the entire cast ia tit* performance; and we hay* no
doubt that the ' Birthright' will, from its intent, interest mi
dramatic power, keep a long and successful possession ot the
stage. Viteheatekerewded nightlv."—Shippittg

" S i r Lytton Bulwer's new Play, T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the soceess
which attended its production. The acting of all the characters
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Play
are of kindred excellence, The scene in the Old Hall, with its
earved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, and
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundle and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the moat
beautiful picture we have teen for many a day. The Play abounds
in strong effects and stirring situations; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching similitudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Belt* Lift in
London"OnThursday, S i r E . L. Bulwer's Play of T H E SEA-CAPT A I N ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced. ItisaDrama
of considerable interest. Of the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence in the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid—the Elizabetn era—the dresse*
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play was given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—Age.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pes of Sir E. L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
the house every night absolutely to overflowing; this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE Sl.A-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success The piece affords many opportunities of producing stfikiHg effects. We htve no doubt that
the play will nave a long career."—Weekly LUtpatoh, Nov. 1.
•' Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph on Thursday
night, and in every respect it is Hkely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, called the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warm
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attraction. It is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resource*
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writing is bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly Memenger.

MtMtnger, Nw. 3 , 1839.
" Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, and before the curtain rets the house wa*
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer was a successful dtateatitt, and," beyond all question, a man of g e n i u t ;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of talent,
such m could be produced at no other Theatre in London. The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third; but
ia i»e fourth, titis stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of a lutrtnt, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
mmuituaw applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever**-. The piece, in fact, was performed as it ean be in no
other house; and en. **,.„,,,„ B B j w e r > amng as much to the
excellence of the acting as to hi* »wn powers, %at achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius.' '—Era.
" S i r E . 1 . Bulwer's new Play of T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Theatre, on Th*r*.
day, and met with an enthusiastic, reception. The Scene where
Norman relate* his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that Dtnds them, it highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where bis obdurate mother denies his claim to bn
her son, and he take* bit stand on his paternal hearth, and assert*
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautifel, and
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the so*.
tunics are impropriate and splendid,"—Athenmum.
"A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either ia plot or language, and the latter is often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. We have rarely seen Mr. Maeread" to greater advantage, T he curtain fell on plenty of applause.'*
—The Argvt.

OPINIONS of the FVBIiIC PRESS

" Sir E. I.. Bui,WF.B obtained a new triumph last night, and
i» every respect it ia likely to be a lasting; triumph. Ilia new
drama, called The SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, 1 HE BIRTHRIGHT,
it certain of a long run ; and coming immediately from the representation, and warm with delight at the performance, we can
hardly see any end to its attraction. It is of a character entirely
different from his three other works of the same class, and shews
extraordinary resources, and a versatility of power for which we
were not fully prepared. We congratulate him leas than the town
on the happy result of the experiment of last night; for he
might rest satisfied with the possession of the faculty to produce
such a play, but the loss to the public, if he did not write, would
ba irreparable. Nothing is more true than the maxim, that, let a
•nan be wanted in any giren circumstances, that man will be
found. Our National Drama warned au author like Bulwer, and
he stood foiward to give it new rigour and animation. All the
performers well deaerved tha strongest testimony to their excelle.ee. We cannot pretend to go through the different scenes and
situations of this admirably-constructed drama. The eonclusirin
of the Fourth Act is one of the most stirring and animating scenes
we remember on the stage, but we despair of giring any notion
of the plot, which can convey to the reader even a faint notion of
she interest excited, and the suspense carried on, almost to the
termination of ilu> drama. The writing is bold and vigorous, and
in a theatre the sine of the Hay-Market it is nut thrown away, as
it often appears to be when delivered in the wider urea of a large
theatre. We do not remember when we have sat out a representation of the kind with more complete satisfaction. We heartily
wieh we had time and space fur a few more qnutations; but we
must refrain, consoling ourselves with the reflection, that our n o de r* will have more delight when they witness the performance of
this beautiful and well-constructed drama. The whole exhibition, from first to last, must have afforded unmixed gratification
toauthor, actors, anil audience."—Morning Ghroniele.
" S i r K . I , Uulwer's new Drama of THE SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced last night. The last Scene in the Fourth Act, is
the great point of the piece—the point, which once doubled, all
wssssfe; and the Sea-Captain finished his voyage triumphantly."
— T i m e s , Nor. !»/.
" Lust night, was produced Sir E. L Bulwer's new drama of
THE 8 E A - C A P T A i N ; o r , THE BIRTHRIGHT. The play
itself was completely successful. The scenes were applauded ait
through ; and when the ' drop fell,' to speak with something like
' execution,' there were shouts of plaudits ; and finally Mr. J .
Webster was allowed (aloud) to announce the drama for repetition ' every evening until farther notice,' amid plenty of applause
and bravos, confirmatory of complete success. It emilains passages of poetry infinitely more true and beautiful than any that
are to lie found in the author's previous dramatic productions,
Macready made as fine a study of the part as the part would
allow; some of his declamation was beautiful, and his action was
worm, powerful, energetic. The passage where Norman asserts
his claims before his guilty mother and Lord Arundel, was
cheered for several minutes. We hare BO space, however, to say
more <4itf merits. It was unequivocally successful, and will,
we have no doubt, draw. It has been carefully got up, with new
scenery and dresses/'—Morning Pott.
" The announcement of Sir E. Lvtton Balwer's new Drama,
THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, drew an overflowing audience to this house last night, every seat not previously
engaged, being occupied almost as soon as the doors were opened.
Every one anticipated a new triumph for the Author, and it would
lethe height of injustice to deny that, as a theatrical representaion.its triumph last night was complete. In the third and fourth
arts the enthusiasm of the audience rose with the interest of the
•Play, which was well sustained in the fifth; till at length, at the
falling of" the cuftain, the audience seemed completely carrreW
away by tbeir feelings, and nearly the whole of the dramatis
persons? were called forward in succession, to receive a repetition
of those enthusiastic plaudits, which had been so liberally bestowed
on them during the progress of the performance."—Courier.
" Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN ; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, which has been for some time in preparation it this theatre, was brought out last night with a cast <>t
characters every way calculated to do a piece justice. The
story is well worked o u t ; Mac ready's part was especially well
suited to him, and we have rarely seen him to greater advantage.
Mr. J. Webster gave out the play for repetition • every evening
till further notice, amidst the loudest nod most general applause.
It is unquestionably a good acting piny, abounding in what are
technically termed ' good situations."—Gloie, Nov. 1, 1839.
'* A new live Act Play, from the pen of Sir Edward Lyttori
Bulwer, entitled The SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this Theatre last evening. The seen*
is laid in the north of Devon, during the reign of Queen Elizabeth— the time occupied by the action is one d a y ; a nearer
approach to the unities than is usual with English dramatists.
Macready has added another laurel to his wreath by his beautiful
impersonation of Norman. His scene with his mother, where he
snakes himself known to her, was magnificent. Che denies his
claim, and calls her menials to thrust him forth—he goes.to the
hearth, and invokes his ancestor; to hail theirson—bis action, hie
look, his utterance, was sublimity itself. He was called for at
the concliisi.il, as were Mrs.Warner, Miss H. Faucit, and Strickland. The Play was given out for repetition every Evening,
amidst the unanimous applause of one of the most crowded houses
we have ever witnessed."—Sun,
" We stated yesterday that the new play of Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer, entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN ; or, THE BIRTHR1GH f, had been produced at this theatre on the pievious evening, and that it had met with complete success. I t is truly
contemptible to observe with what feeling and acumen lb» politittl bins of our contemporaries of the daily press is made subservient in their infective notices of this new play; m though
plevrighl and poittwiiwti were evuonyniuui terms, and the draws a
mere shutfWwk (or partisanship. Had the author of the • Birthright' been known ewjjas a dramatic author, the public, would
probably have bee. afforded, through the press, the means of
judging, in some m«*s«re, of the character or merits of tbe drama
in question ; but we feel convinced that from the Whig or Tory
Jor what yon-like} criticisms thus put forth, it would be »« difficult to form an opinion as to define, the affinity between plays aud
politics. Then* strictures, moreover, (whose observance of party
unanimity is Wonderful, and whose tendency, thus distinguished,
is to the antipodes) will add but little to the lustre of literature,
and advantage test the cause of the drama. But enough. We
may quietly HOW our H u t that no such dictates govern our
Ikssapts, or tyranny dare guide our pen. As a drama, the
' Birthright' is more replete with varied and exciting interest than
•itfcer of die author's former productions, and is certainly not less
ri*h in the paetic beauties with which his writings arc known toi
abound Mr. Macready has many passages in the play, of striking power an) beauty, which we nave neither time nor space now
to particularize. His conception and action of the part were all
that could «* desired. Indeed the saute remark is almost equally
applicable to the entire cant in the performance; and we have no
doubt that the ' Birthright* will, from its intense interest and

the chatnteter of a romantic play than we have noticed in any previous irswnatic effort of ant writer; and, read or viewed with use
half of that attawance which ia properly claimed for the machinery of action and movement by the romantic stage, its effect ia
unquestionably great and powerful. The p«y, better acted than
it could possibly have been at any other place, secured its triumphant success."—fixaminrr.

Sir Lytton Bulwer's new Play, T H E 8EA-CAPTAI IT; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday, with
triumphant success. Anything more enthusiastic (we will not say
general) and gratifying to the Author, we never witnessed. For
the sake of Manager and Author we rejoice to record the suceeaa
which attended its productioB. The acting of all the character,
is admirable. The Scenery and general presentment of the Play
are ol kindred excellence. The scene in the Old Hall, with it*
carved pannels, its huge hearth, pictures and escutcheons, ami
the picturesque group, formed at the table in the centre, by Lady
Arundfe and Violet listening to the sailor's story, is the moat
beautiful picture we have seen fnrmany a day. The Play abound*
instrong effects nod stirring situations ; there are some exquisite
figures, some very fine lines, some very tender and touching eimi" .itudes. It will doubtless be extremely popular."—Bell's Life in
London
" On Thursday, S i r E . L. Bulwer's Play of THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or, THE BIRTHRIGHT, wasproduced. ItisaDrama
of considerable interest. Ol" the acting we can speak in unqualified terms. The lessee has spared no expence ia the getting up of
the Play. The Scenery, by Phillips, is quite in keeping with the
period in which the scene is laid-—the Elizabeth era—the dresses
and appointments are also equally correct. ' Good wine needs no
bush.' The Play wa? given out for every evening until further
notice, and will doubtless have a run."—.dge.
" The Hay-Market, in, we suppose, an exuberance of liberality, has brought out a new play, from the pea of Sir E. L. Bulwer, notwithstanding that the previous performances had filled
' the house every night absolutely to overflowingj this liberality
creates permanent claims upon public favour. Sir Edward Bulwer's new play, THE SEA-CAPTAIN, was produced on Thursday night, with decided success. The piece affords many opportunities ol producing striking effects. We have no doubt that
the play will have a long career."-— Weekly Dispatch, Nov. I.
" Sir E. L. Bulwer obtained a new triumph on Thursday
night, and m every respect it is likely to be a lasting triumph.
His new drama, oalled the SEA-CAPTAIN, is certain of a long
run ; and, coming immediately from the representation, and warn
with delight at the performance, we can hardly see an end to its
attraction. It is of a character entirely different from his three
other works of the same class, and shows extraordinary resources
and a versatility of power for which we were not fully prepared.
The writing is bold and vigorous."—Bell's Weekly Messenger.
" On Thursday evening, a new serious play, in five acts, by
Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer, was produced at this theatre; and,
affording Mr. Macready some fine opportunities for the manifestation of his unrivalled power as a master of human emotions
ind passions, it was very successful.*'—New Bell'*
Weekly
Messenger, Nov :i, 1839.
" Last Thursday evening a new Play, by Sir E. Lytton Bulwer,
was produced at this Theatre. The announcement attracted a
crowded audience, aud before the curtain rose the house waa
crammed to the roof. They remembered that Bulwer'was a successful dramatist, and, 'beyond all question, a man of genius ;
and they saw before them on the stage a constellation of. talent,
such as could be produced at no other Theatre in London The
interest opened in the second act, and increased in the third; but
in the fourth, this stately stream of passion acquired the impetuosity
of n torrent, and the drop-scene of the act fell amidst thunders of
tumultuous applause, upon one of the most successful pieces we
ever saw, The piece, n fact, was performed as it can be in u .
other bouse ; and Sir I . Lytton Bulwer, owing as much to the
excellence of the acting as to his ewn powers, has achieved by it
one of the greatest triumphs of his genius."—Era.
" S i r E . L . Bulwer's new Play of'THE SEA-CAPTAIN; or,
THE BIRTHRIGHT, was brought out at this Tlieatre, on Thursday, and met with an enthusiastic reception, "FHe Scene where
Norman relates his escape from drowning to the Countess, he not
knowing at this time the tie that binds them, is highly dramatic.
Another Scene, where his obdurate mother denies his claim to be
her son, and he takes his stand on his paternal hearth, and asserts
his right of heirship, defying the menials who had been called to
eject him, produced a striking effect. The Scenery, taken principally from Nash's ' Old English Mansions,' is beautiful, m d
made us forget that we were at the Hay-Market; and the costumes are appropriate and splendid.''—Atherueum.
" A new Play entitled T H E SEA-CAPTAIN; or, T H E
' BIRTHRIGHT, was produced here on Thursday night, with success. We think Sir Edward improves as a dramatist—there is no
immorality either in plot or language, and the latter is often very
pretty and occasionally poetical. W efcsverarely seen Mr. Maeready to greater advantage. The curtain fell on plenty of applause."
" The little Theatre*, as it is still terined,tbrough habit, though
not so little either, was crowded in every part on Thursday
evening, by an audience anxious to assist at the first representation of Sir Edward Lylton Bulwer's new play of The SEA-CAPT A I N ; or, The B I R T H R I G H T . The play was rapt.rously
received by the audience, and will have what is technically called
ft run. I t is equal in poetic beauty and originality of thought
to the " lady of Lyons," or " Richelieu."—John Bull.
'• Sir Edw. Lytton Bulwer's new play, The SEA-CAPTAIN,
was produced for the first tine at this theatre on Thursday
last. The success was unequivocal and complete. . . . .
" Such is a hasty sketch of one of the moat charming play*
we have ever seeu or heard. The dialogue is only such as Buiwercan write. In die march of his plot the author has proved
himself to be a perfect master of dramatic effect, every act t e c
ninating with a thrilling event, each suspending by its doubtfu
import all opinion as to the final denouement.
The acting
throughout was tine to perfection."—Court Journal.
" Sir E. Lytton Bulwer may well laugh at newspaper criticism
seeing that ihe writers of the aitiiles in the various morning
journals have hern governed much nwrc by poHtieal feeling than
by sound discretion and fair judgment. They could not deny
that his new drama, I he SEA-CAPTAIN, met with the most
iriuinphiuit success, bui they did their " little possible," to show
that it was a mistake, mid by hinting a fault here, and picking
a hole there, to establish the worthlessness of popular approbation. We bold it to be a work of high genius, and if we are
not much mistaken, it will long continue an acting play— w*
meau long otter the first run, and long even after the ftrit season."—Observer.
" O n Thursday night the SEA-CAPTAIN made his firstvoy.
age, or perhaps we ought to say, arrived safe and sound, nit only
in the haven of love, but, what is of more consequence to actcr,
author, and manager, rides safely at anchor in the good graces of
the public. We are not of those who admit politics to bias over
opinions."—Parthenon.
" S i r E. L. Bulwer's Play, IU Five Acts, called The SEAC A P T A I N ; or, T H E BIRTHRIGHT, was produced at this
house on Thursday night, and proved highly successful. Tke
Play was announced for repetition every evening; and ive have
nodoubt it will draw good houses,"—Court Gazette.
'• On Thursday, Sir Edward L. Bulwers play of THK SEACAPTAIN ; or THE B1KTHR1GHT, was produced bete t . an
audience crowded in every part, and with the moat unlfouaded
and deserved success. ' Most deserved,' for both in action and
poetry it is a noble dramatic production; the plot and leading
characters possessing much originality, and the incidents and
situations turning upon them being, consequently, novel and
effective. Nothing could exceed the success of the whole, and
the management may put on its nightcap for the rest of the
M M while the public crowd to have feetr every night's enjoyments of a public drama acted in a masterly style*. The period »
die Elizabethan age."~tUttrary
Gazette. "
